At every stage of the journey the popular enthusiasm had a new force and a new significance, but it was at Delhi that the real impulse was felt.

headline: DUKE GOES AWAY, HOPING TO RETURN; Appreciates New York Hospitality, and Is Sure King George Would Enjoy a Visit to Us.
leadPara: The Duke and Duchess of Connaught and Princess Patricia left New York last evening for Ottawa, in the official car of the Canadian Government, the York, which was attached to the Montreal Express, leaving the Grand Central Station, at 7:25. Just before leaving the Duke expressed himself, through his secretary and aid, Lieut. Col. Lowther, as having had a jolly good time.
abstract: Connaughts leave NYC for return to Canada

headline: TAFT GOING TO OHIO; But Will Spend To-night and To-morrow in New York.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- President Taft leaves Washington to-morrow on a five days' trip that will take him to New York, Cleveland, Columbus, and Akron, Ohio, the most important journey, in the eyes of many of his freinds, that he has planned since he got back from the West. The President was still suffering to-night from a cold.

headline: INDORSE ALL INSURGENTS.; Illinois Conference Averts Row by Avoiding Mention of Names.
leadPara: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 27. -- The La Follette men bluffed Roosevelt's supporters in the insurgent State Convention today, and as a result neither gets an indorsement for President or any other office.
abstract: Illinois Repub state conv endorses all insurgents

headline: TAFT MEN READY TO FIGHT BARNES; No Inclination to Accept Plan for an Uninstructed Delegation -- Confer with Taft To-day.
leadPara: Friends of President Taft in the Republican State organization will make a fight, if necessary, for an instructed delegation to the Republican National Convention in Chicago. This became known immediately after a meeting of the Republican State Committee yesterday, at which a line-up of the "progressive" and "Old Guard" members was forced unexpectedly, with the result that the progressives prevailed by a vote of 20 to 14.
abstract: Taft friends ready to fight Barnes efforts to send uninstructed delegation to natl conv

headline: SCHURMAN FOR TAFT.; Has Made a Proud Record for Republican Party, Says Cornell Head.
leadPara: CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 27. -- Indorsing the present Administration in the highest of terms and declaring that he is for Taft, Jacob G. Schurman, President of the Cornell University, declared here this afternoon that President Taft has made a record for the Republican Party of which the party had a right to be proud.
abstract: Cornell Univ pres J G Schurman endorses Taft

headline: SPURNED OFFER OF RYAN'S AID; So Says McCombs, Who Is Trying to Make Wilson President.
leadPara: To the personal denials of Gov. Woodrow Wilson that he had ever authorized Col. Henry Watterson to collect campaign cash for his Presidential boom, was added yesterday in emphatic tones, the complete denial of the only other person who might by any chance have spoken in Woodrow Wilson's name, or handled funds for him when raised.
abstract: McCombs issues statement denying he authorized Watterson to solicit funds from Ryan

headline: BLUCHER SEEN THROUGH HAZE; First Biography in English of the Great Marshal Proves Misty and Unsatisfying
leadPara: BLUECHER, as Ernest F. Henderson remarks in his preface,* is chiefly known to English readers as the man who came to Wellington's aid at Waterloo, whereas he had a separate existence of his own. He was one of the great figures of the Napoleonic era; yet he has never before been made the subject of an English biography, and of his German lives none has been translated into English.

headline: OHIOANS HERE SHOW LOYALTY TO TAFT; " We'll Stick to You," the Keynote of Dinner, Where He Talks Against Recall of Judges. of Judges.
leadPara: President Taft was the guest of honor at the twenty-sixth annual dinner of the Ohio Society in the Waldorf-Astoria last night, and he got a reception that was as noisy as it was cordial, all of which his friends took as an indication that he is still Ohio's most popular Republican son.
abstract: In NYC; goes to bro Henry's home; attends dinners of Ohio Soc, West Virginia Soc and Aero Club and Daughters of Jacob benefit ball; s at all

headline: SOCIALISM AROUSES RULE BY TUMULT; Declares Attorney General Carmody in Debate with Hillquit at New Rochelle Forum.
leadPara: Attorney General Thomas Carmody and Morris Hillquit, the Socialist leader, debated on "Individualism vs. Socialism" before the New Rochelle People's Forum yesterday afternoon. Mr. Carmody declared that those who sought to build up political power by leveling the courts were the worst enemies of the American Government.
abstract: Rev Dr J Silverman attacks Socialism as false outlook on life, ser, Temple Emanu-El, NYC

headline: SIX GOVERNORS NOW IN ROOSEVELT BOOM; Stubbs of Kansas Says They Have Gauged Sentiment and the Colonel Will Be Named.
leadPara: Interesting revelations of the manner in which the pro-Roosevelt propaganda is being spread through the coalition of six Republican Governors in various States were made yesterday by Gov. Walter R. Stubbs of Kansas in an interview in his apartments at the Hotel Wolcott. Incidentally the name of Gov. Chester B. Aldrich of Nebraska was added to the list of Gubernatorial advocates of the Roosevelt cause.

headline: COMBINE TO FIGHT TAFT.; Roosevelt and La Follette Factions in Nebraska Join Forces.
leadPara: OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 28. -- Roosevelt and La Follette will no longer fight each other in Nebraska, representatives of both factions having agreed to-day to combine forces against Taft. Col. John O. Yeiser of Omaha acted for the Roosevelt interests, and Don C. Van Dusen, member of the La Follette State Executive Committee, represented the Wisconsin Senator.
abstract: Roosevelt and La Follette factions in Nebraska join forces against Taft

headline: FIDDLING BOB' STIRS TENNESSEE DINERS; Aged Senator Taylor Recites Parts of "The Fiddle and the Bow" for Southerners.
leadPara: Three hundred and fifty Tennesseans of this city heard "Fiddling Bob" Taylor, United States Senator and former Governor of their native State, recite passages of the famous address, "The Fiddle and the Bow," which, because of his unusual voice and power of melody, he has made almost as popular as "Dixie" itself, throughout the Southern States.
abstract: Sen L Lea urges more sympathy between business and pol, s, Tennessee Soc of NYC

headline: ROOSEVELT BOOMERS RICH CHICAGO MEN; Who Assert They Have Never Consulted the Colonel or Asked His Consent.
leadPara: CHICAGO, Jan. 29. -- For the first time the facts connected with the launching of the Roosevelt boom for a renomination for the Presidency were made public here to-day. It had been supposed by some here that the movement originated among corporate interests antagonistic to the Taft administration, yet afraid of the progressive Republicanism as represented by the La Follette insurgents.
abstract: Repub County Exec Com endorses Taft

headline: TAFT INVADES OHIO; MAKES FIVE SPEECHES; He Omits All Reference to the Insurgent Movement or His Own Candidacy.
leadPara: CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 29. -- President Taft's invasion of Ohio, his home State, began in Cleveland to-day with five speeches, incidental to receptions and dinners.
abstract: Taft appeals for treaties approval, s, Cleveland C of C

headline: Article 3 -- No Title
STEEL BILL PASSED BY HOUSE, 210 TO 109; Twenty Insurgents Join with Democratic Majority in Supporting Tariff Reduction.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- The Underwood-Palmer bill for the revision of the iron and steel schedule of the Payne tariff law passed the House late this afternoon by a vote of 210 to 109. Only minor charges to correct typographical errors were made. The bill, as passed, is identical in every essential with the original draft as ratified by the Democratic caucus.

headline: ROOSEVELT WILL NOT DECLINE IF NAMED; Editor Abbott of The Outlook Gives This Assurance to Ex-Gov. Stokes.
leadPara: The New Jersey boom for Col. Theodorse Roosevelt for President, started by progressive Republicans of that State, received added impetus when about thirty prominent New Jersey Republicans met at the Union Club, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-first Street, yesterday afternoon and discussed ways and means to bring the Roosevelt candidacy actively before the New Jersey voters.

headline: TAFT CALLS HALT ON PROGRESSIVES; Time to Demand That They Cease Their Attacks, He Tells Ohio Republicans.
leadPara: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 30. -- Reviewing the achievements of his Administration before the Columbus Glee Club here to- night, President Taft drew the line sharply between the old-line Republicans and the progressives of his party and practically declared that the time was at hand when the "denunciation" by the progressives must cease and when the Nation will demand facts.
abstract: 30 NJ Repubs, headed by Fort and Stokes, conf, NYC, on ways and means to boom Roosevelt in NJ; Abbott lr to Stokes gives it as his opinion that Roosevelt would accept nomination; lr text; La Follette losing out to Roosevelt in Illinois; Kings County Repub Com comes out for Taft; Taft revs his Adm's achievements and says it is now time for Repub progressives to cease their attacks, s, Columbus (Ohio) Glee Club; holds Repub victory in Nov elections certain; L C Laylin to replace A I Vorys as Taft's campaign mgr; Koenig says Roosevelt will support Taft when he is nominated, s, Repub Club, Bklyn; NYC Controller Prendergast comes out for Roosevelt, s, Greene County Soc

headline: WASHINGTON FOR ROOSEVELT.; La Follette Boom Collapses When Progressives Desert Him.
leadPara: TACOMA, Wash., Jan. 31. -- The La Follette boom in Washington has collapsed during the last week owing to a Statewide movement to elect a Roosevelt delegation to the Republican National Convention. Nearly all the progressive leaders in the State have joined the Roosevelt movement, including many who were La Follette supporters.

headline: MR. HOVEY'S LIFE OF MORGAN.; Mr. Underwood's Availability.
abstract: lr urging O W Underwood be nominated for Pres

headline: THE MONEY TRUST DILEMMA.
leadPara: The embarrassment of the Democrats regarding the investigation of the money trust is one of the most encouraging signs of the times. Only a little while ago the thing would have gone through with a whoop, but now it is necessary to caucus about it or abandon it.

headline: HERRICK MAY ACCEPT.; His Reply to Taft's Offer of Paris Ambassadorship Expected Soon.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- It is expected that a definite answer will shortly reach the White House from Myron T. Herrick, former Governor of Ohio, accepting or declining the vacant Ambassadorship to France. The President is reported to have offered him the post, and indications are that the Governor did not decline.
abstract: Ex-Gov M T Herrick may accept apptmt as Amb to France

headline: 'ARIANE ET BARBE-BLEUE' AT OPERA; Paul Dukas's Setting of Maeterlinck's Drama Revived. MISS FARRAR AS ARIANE A Fine Performance of a Work of the Modern French School Not Easily Popular.
leadPara: Paul Dukas's opera, "Ariane et Barbe-Bleue," a setting of Maeterlinck's drama, which was first given at the Metropolitan Opera House last March, was revived there last evening. Its reception by the audience seemed to leave as much doubt as was felt last season whether or not this very characteristic product of the new and prevalent French School of music had really found a place in the esteem or even the understanding of the public.
abstract: Ariane et Barbe-Bleue, by P Dukas and M Maeterlinck: G Farrar stars, Met

headline: Article 1 -- No Title
TAFT'S NOMINATION SURE, SAYS HILLES; Secretary Brings President's Campaign Into the Open with a New Stride.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, D.C., Feb. 1. -- The campaign for President Taft's renomination to-day took a new stride, and for the first time came out into the open with a confident blast. The friends of the President have always insisted that his strength was far greater than appeared in face of the loud Roosevelt and La Follette talk, and there have been signs recently that a more aggressive policy would soon be taken by the Administration backers.
abstract: returns to Washington, DC, after short stop in Pittsburgh

headline: WHERE'S THE NEWSIES' UNION.; Mr. Roosevelt Is "Willin."
abstract: lr on Abbott rept Roosevelt will run

headline: WILL THE KAISER HAVE TO MOVE FROM BERLIN?
leadPara: IS the Kaiser any longer safe at Berlin, or even at Potsdam? That is the question which many are asking of one another to-day in Germany as well as abroad.

headline: HARMON'S BOOM NOW ON.; Ohio Congressmen Open Headquarters in Washington.
THE SCHOOLMASTER IN POLITICS AS THE WITS SEE HIM; Some Ancient Incidents When the Professor Met the Soldier in Political Field, and Good Stories of the Classroom and Its Head.
leadPara: ONCE more the cry has been raised that the schoolmaster is invading politics. At present and at home his welcome is a distinctly derisive one. The academic point of view and the academic mind are not popular with the masses. Col Watterson's characterization of Gov. Woodrow Wilson as "a schoolmaster and not a statesman" was confessedly not meant to be flattering.

headline: DISCUSS PROBLEMS OF STATEN ISLAND; Business Men Suggest Installment Method in Paying for Expensive Improvements.
leadPara: At a recent meeting of the Board of Directors of the Staten Island Chamber of Commerce the question of public improvements on the island was taken up for consideration. For the purposes of expressing the views of the Directors a committee was appointed consisting Thomas A. Fulton, Mast Ruttenan, and the Secretary of the Chamber, Cornelius G. Kolff, which has submitted the following report:

headline: PALESTINE ZIONISTS PROSPER; Own Their Own Farms, Says H.E. Clark, Back for Short Stay.
leadPara: Among the passengers arriving yesterday on the White Star liner Arabic from Liverpool was Herbert E. Clark, who was American Vice-Consul in Jerusalem for eighteen years. He resigned on Jan. 1. When asked by a TIMES reporter if the war between Italy and Turkey had caused any bad feeling between Christians and Mohammedans in Palestine and Syria, Mr. Clark said:
abstract: Former Amer Consul H E Clark tells of Zionists progress in colonizing Palestine

headline: THE NEW TASK OF FRANCE.
leadPara: The French Government has now entered formally upon the task of establishing a Protectorate over Morocco, and its course will be followed with close attention in all the Chancelleries of the old World. It still remains to come to some definite agreement with Spain, but this is well advanced and the better spirit shown by the Poincare Ministry is a fair guarantee that it will be carried through.
abstract: ed on France's task of establishing protectorate

headline: LA FOLLETTE NOW OUT OF THE RACE; Manager Announces End of Personal Campaign, but Continued Fight for Principles.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The Presidential candidacy of Senator Robert M. La Follette has practically come to an end, following his collapse at the dinner of the Periodical Publishers' Association in Philadelphia last Friday night. A statement issued from La Follette headquarters hero to-night comes as near admitting the plain fact as could be expected.
abstract: halts active campaigning but remains candidate for Pres nomination

headline: LA FOLLETTE BITTER AGAINST ROOSEVELT; His Collapse Thought Partly Due, to Disappointment Over the ex-President's Boom.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Increasingly strong representations yesterday and today of the embarassment he is causing his firends and the Progressive campaign have failed to move Senator La Follette a peg from his determination to leave his name as a Presidential candidate before the country, though he has practically decided to leave the country for many weeks and drop out of the lists of active campaigners.
abstract: La Follette reptd bitter at Roosevelt boom progress

headline: ROOSEVELT MUST LEAD PROGRESSIVES; So Says Amos Pinchot, and Invites Them All to "Get Behind" the Colonel.
leadPara: Certain illusory features of the Roosevelt boom were destroyed yesterday and the Colonel brought more openly into line by a statement issued by Amos Pinchot, brother of Gifford, the Colonel's friend, wile was deposed as Forestry Commissioner by President Taft.
abstract: A Pinchot issues statement saying progressives are now free to get behind Roosevelt as result of La Follette withdrawal

headline: MINNESOTA BARS ROOSEVELT.; Progressives Prefer to Give Delegation to Senator Clapp.
SEEK ROOSEVELT DECLARATION.; Leaders in Chicago Conference Plan to Force His Hand.
leadPara: CHICAGO, Ill., Feb. 7. -- Tentative plans of the National Roosevelt leaders, who will hold their first conference in Chicago next Saturday, contemplate personal appeal to Col. Roosevelt to make a statement to the American people and let them know that he will accept the nomination if it is offered him.

headline: AGREEMENT ON CHINA IS SUGGESTED BY US; We Oppose Granting of Loans Without the Approval of All the Powers.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The State Department to-day made public a note defining the attitude of the United States toward China in the conditions now prevailing in that country.
abstract: US State Dept makes pub its note to Amb Count von Bernstorff defining its attitude on current conditions; text; Russian-Chinese relations in Peking noted

headline: MORSE ON THE WAY; STUDIES THE MARKETS; Goes to the Train at Atlanta in a Roller Chair, but Doesn't Look a Sick Man.
leadPara: ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 7. -- Charles W. Morse is on his way to New York on the Birmingham Special of the Southern Railway, and on Thursday afternoon will be back near the scene of his financial operations, which sent him to the Atlanta Penitentiary on a fifteen-year sentence, if there is no delay when his train reaches Washington at 10:40 tomorrow morning.

headline: TO WORK FOR ROOSEVELT.; Progressive League Will Aid His Boom in Ohio.
SEASONABLE CONFUSION.
leadPara: An observer who from a mountain top should survey the field of our politics might well conclude that both parties are headed straight for destruction, that nobody can be elected this Fall, and that the Presidency must accordingly lapse unless Mr. TAFT be permitted to continue in office as a "hold-over" President.
abstract: Editorial on confustion in ranks and among leaders of both parties

headline: ROOSEVELT QUOTES LINCOLN'S LETTERS; The Colonel Shows That Another Great Man Also Was Wary of Arming His Enemies.
leadPara: Col. Theodore Roosevelt, forced more into the open as a result of the collapse of the La Follette boom than at any time since his friends have been grooming him for the 1912 Republican nomination, fell back upon Abraham Lincoln yesterday as an excuse for not making a declaration as to his stand at this time. He quoted the martyred President to prove that his present policy of silence is the best one for him.

headline: ROOSEVELT TO FIGHT TO END--NO DESERTER; Tells Progressives, Through A.P. Moore, That He Will Not Abandon Their Cause.
leadPara: Col. Roosevelt pushed his band wagon a little further along the road to the Presidential nomination yesterday by issuing a message to progressive Republicans through A.P. Moore, editor of The Pittsburgh Leader. The message was designed to convince the progressives that the Colonel had their best interests at heart and that he would never desert them -- no, never.
abstract: Roosevelt tells progressive Repubs, through A P Moore, he will not desert the cause and will fight to the end

headline: TAFT DROPS BOTH HOOK AND NAGEL; Nagel's Brewery Connections Thought to Have Barred Him from Supreme Court.
abstract: Hook and Nagel reptd out of the running; objections to them noted

headline: SOCIALIST VICE PRESIDENT; Beats Conservative for Reichstag Post -- Centrist Defeats Bebel for President.
leadPara: BERLIN, Feb. 9. -- Dr. Peter Spahn, the leader of the Clerical Centre Party, was elected President of the Reichstag today, defeating August Bebel, the leader of the Social Democratic Party, by 196 votes to 175.
abstract: Reichstag election; Clerical Centre Party leader Dr P Spahn Pres, Socialist P Scheidemann 1st Vice Pres and Natl Liberal H S Paasche 2d Vice Pres

headline: CLEVELAND MOVE FOR COLONEL.; All Factions Except Taft Supporters Attend Meeting.
leadPara: CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 10. -- Republicans, representing all factions in Cuyahoga except Taft's supporters, met today and organized under the banner of Theodore Roosevelt. While John D. Fackler, La Follette leader in Ohio, was not present, he war represented by several members of the Progressive League, who came to throw its support in Cuyahoga to Roosevelt.
abstract: Wilson hdqrs to be opened in Cleveland

headline: OHIOANS TO AID WILSON.; Anti-Harmon Element Will Establish Headquarters in Cleveland.
CUMMINS AGAINST HERRICK.; Other Senate Progressives Also Object to Him as Ambassador.
abstract: Sen A B Cummins to lead fight against apptmt

headline: MORE UNIFORMITY IN MOTORING LAWS; Noticeable Change in Recent Attitude of Public and Legislators Toward Motor Vehicles.
leadPara: Motorists who have made a close study of automobile legislation declare there has been a noticeable change, during the past year, in the attitude of the public and legislators toward motor vehicle legislation, which in many States was primarily urged for revenue-producing purposes and to effect proper means of identification.

headline: WARNING ROOSEVELT.; Rocky Mountain Progressives Threaten to Desert the Colonel.
abstract: Rocky Mt States progressives threaten to quit Roosevelt unless he drops G Pinchot as active campaign member

headline: SURVEY OF JEWISH SCHOOLS.; The Talmud Torah, of Ancient Origin, One of Several Systems in Use.
leadPara: The Bureau of Education of the Jewish Community (Kehillah) of New York City has published a survey of the financial status of the Jewish Religious Schools of New York. Dr. S. Benderly, Director of the bureau, provides details of the different congregational and institutional schools, and of the Chedarim (private) and Talmud Torah (communal) Schools, which give religious education to children attending secular public schools.
abstract: Kehillah (Jewish community) of NY issues survey of financial status of Jewish religious schools in NYC

headline: Article 17 -- No Title
leadPara: MRS. JOHN DE WITT WARNER of 901 Lexington Avenue and her daughter, Mrs. William Joshua Barney, gave an auction bridge party on Friday afternoon.

headline: EIGHT GOVERNORS IN A ROOSEVELT LEAGUE; With Delegates from Twenty-four States, They Organize in Chicago for Campaign Work.
leadPara: CHICAGO, Feb. 10. -- Speeding eastward as fast as steam can carry him is a confidential messenger of the National Roosevelt Committee, who carries with him a remarkable memorial bearing the signatures of no less than eight Governors, and addressed to Col. Theodore Roosevelt, Oyster Bay, L.I.
abstract: Natl Roosevelt Com, after conf on method to be used to elect Roosevelt, sends memorial to him signed by 8 Govs asking if he will accept nomination; com members listed

headline: FOR RECALL OF JUDGES.; Senator Clapp Tells New York University Men of His Attitude.
abstract: Sen M E Clapp favors initiative, referendum and recall, s, NYU

headline: Article 12 -- No Title
LIMITS PANAMA FREIGHT.; Stimson Doesn't Want It to Interfere with Work on the Canal.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- To avoid interference with construction of the Panama Canal Secretary Stimson issued an order to day which will restrict the amount of freight to be accepted for transportation over the Panama Railroad. The freight rates will not be increased.
abstract: Progressive Canal & Commercial Assn complains to Supt Peck of obstacles to safe navigation on NYS canals

headline: TAFT EAGER TO FIGHT.; Wants to Denounce Lies and Hypocrisy and No Longer Fears Defeat.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- President Taft and Senator Root of New York sounded an aggressive note for the coming National campaign in speeches they delivered early this morning before the League of Republican State Clubs at the Willard Hotel. The occasion was the league's annual dinner.
abstract: Roosevelt takes Govs memorial under consideration; Taft cites eagerness to denounce lies and hypocrisy, s, Repub State Clubs League, Washington, DC; Sen E Root says Repubs need not fear vote of country

headline: THE GAME OF THE GOVERNORS.
BOOM ROOSEVELT IN ST. PAUL.; Rift Among La Follette Men -- Senator Too Ill to Run, Pinchot Wires.
leadPara: ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 11. -- Hugh T. Halbert, who resigned last night from the Board of Directors of the Minnesota Progressive Republican League, following the board's indorsement of Senator Robert M. La Follette for the Presidential nomination, announced his intention today of forming an organization of the supporters of Theodore Roosevelt in Minnesota.
abstract: H T Halbert to form orgn of Roosevelt backers in Minnesota

headline: HARVEY TO SEE DIX.; Albany Politicians Say New York Will Be Obscured at Convention.
leadPara: ALBANY, Feb. 11. -- Politicians do not look upon the prospective visit of Col. George Harvey to the Executive Chambers as of any political significance. It is not expected that New York will cut an important figure in the National Convention this year.

headline: LA FOLLETTE STAYS IN RACE.; Wisconsin Senator Tells Minnesota Progressives He'll Not Withdraw.
abstract: La Follette sends message to Minnesota Progressive Repub League saying he is still in race

headline: TAFT FIRES ON HIS OPPONENTS; Refers to Them as Extremists Who Would Bring Conditions of French Revolution.
leadPara: In a ringing speech last night President Taft replied to all who are opposing his election under the guise of progressives, whether Republican or Democratic. He mentioned no names and made no accusations of disloyalty, but as he cast scorn on the doctrine of the recall of the judiciary his audience thought of Oyster Bay and cheered loudly.
abstract: Taft says extremists are not progressives and would bring US into condition parallel to French Revolution, s, NYC; revs Adm record; s text

headline: TAFT ADMITTED RAY AIDED HIS CAMPAIGN; Did So "At Instance of My Brother," He Said in Letter to Whipple Urging Leniency.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- President Taft's "personal and confidential" letters to Brig. Gen. Charles H. Whipple, retiring Paymaster of the Army, regarding the case of Major Beecher B. Ray, the Army Paymaster, who is alleged to have enjoyed immunity from various troubles through political influence, were made public to-day after being again read to the House Committee on Expenditures in the War Department.
abstract: lrs made pub by com; texts; reveal Taft admitted Ray aided his campaign

headline: BUSINESS NEED NOT FEAR, SAYS WILSON; But It Must Be Separated from Politics, He Urges, if Ills Are to be Cured.
leadPara: CHICAGO, Feb. 12. -- Expressing the opinion that the country's business has nothing to fear from the application of progressive policies to the administration of public affairs, Gov. Woodrow Wilson of New Jersey opened his campaign here for the Democratic Presidential nomination in an address before 600 men at the Iroquois' Club's Lincoln birthday luncheon to-day.
abstract: Wilson says business need not fear progressive policies applied to adm of pub affairs but holds it must separate itself from pol, s, Chicago

headline: ROOSEVELT'S WORDS TURNED AGAINST HIM; " Commended" for Saying He Wouldn't Run Again by Virginians, Who Indorse Taft.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- What was promptly hailed as the Administration answer to the eight Governors and others who have declared for the nomination of Col. Roosevelt was contained in the resolutions adopted to-day by the Republican convention in the Eighth Virginia District, which met in Alexandria to elect delegates and alternates to the Chicago convention.
abstract: 8th Virginia Dist Repub conv supports Taft

headline: SENATE MONEY INQUIRY PLAN; Progressives of Both Parties Favor One by Special Committee.
abstract: both pol parties to propose joint legis com probe

headline: ROOSEVELT TO MEET CHICAGO EMISSARY; Hurries Here to Receive Delegate from Progressives Who Are Backing Him.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, N.Y., Feb. 12. -- Col. Roosevelt left this evening for New York. Before leaving he received a communication to the effect that he would be waited on there, probably to-morrow morning, by a delegate from the conference of Progressives, held in Chicago last Saturday, at which a letter was prepared asking him to define definitely his position.
abstract: O Madden jailed as suspect

headline: TAFT ROW IN COLORADO.; Progressives Declare Federal Machine Packed Committee Meeting.
leadPara: DENVER, Col., Feb. 12. -- A statement asserting that to-day's meeting of the Republican State Central Committee, which indorsed President Taft for renomination by a vote of 103 to 10, was "packed with Federal office holders" and alleging that no fewer than thirty Postmasters appointed by President Taft were in attendance, was issued by Philip B. Stuart and other progressive Republicans after the meeting of the committee.
abstract: progressive Repubs charge Colorado State Central Com that endorsed Taft was packed with Fed office holders

headline: DOCTOR BRYAN'S OPINION.
leadPara: " Think it would be suicidal to nominate HARMON or any one else favored "by Wall Street," said Mr. BRYAN in his telegram to Senator GORE. In a sense Mr. BRYAN is an expert in these matters; that is, he is half an expert. He knows how to compound an infallibly fatal prescription.
abstract: Editorial scores Bryan opinion on who should be nominated

headline: HOT WORDS FOR TAFT FROM PROGRESSIVES; President's Policy 'Murder and Suicide' and Attacks on Roosevelt 'Political Paranoia.'
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- With the opening here to-day of the offices of the Roosevelt National Committee in the Munsey Building, Medill McCormick, who is in charge, gave out a signed statement which makes it more plain than heretofore that the Colonel's friends have decided to concentrate their political fire on President Taft in their efforts to put his predecessor again in the White House.
abstract: M McCormick in reply says Taft backers are led by reactionaries

headline: THE PATHOLOGY OF THE PROGRESSIVES.
leadPara: President TAFT'S diagnosis of the case of the Progressives seems to be pretty sound. It finds support in the appearance and symptoms of the patients; we think it will be confirmed by the autopsy. These extremists, he said in his Lincoln's Birthday speech in this city, "are not Progressives -- they are political emotionalists or neurotics."
abstract: ed, The Pathology of the Progressives, on Taft statement

headline: ROOSEVELT BOOM IN BERGEN.; Taft Attacked at Ono Hackensack Meeting; Praised at Another.
leadPara: HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 14. -- The Bergen County Progressive Republican League gave its second annual dinner at the Hotel Susquehanna here this evening. President Herbert M. Bailey presided and William T. Knight of Bogota was toastmaster. On the programme appeared the following sentence, credited to Col. headline: NO LONGER A REPUBLICAN.

headline: FOR CHINA'S INTEGRITY.; Germany, England, Russia, and Japan Agree to Knox Note.

headline: COL. LYON AGAINST PRIMARY.; Roosevelt's Texas Friend Thinks the Plan Socialistic.

Roosevelt is pressing for Presidential preference primaries has led the Taft men to wonder why his lieutenants refuse to hold such primaries in a State where they control the organization. leadPara: ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 9. -- A quieter or a more perfunctory Republican State Convention than the one which William Barnes, Jr., Chairman of the Republican State Committee, called to order here at noon to-day would be hard to imagine. It was run by approved steam roller methods, and during the two hours or so it lasted, when adjournment was taken for 10:30 o'clock to-morrow morning, there wasn't a ripple of opposition, Rooseveltian or otherwise.

Roosevelt's advocacy of the recall of judicial decisions and the acceptance of that doctrine by Pontius Pilate when he accepted the verdict of the people and condemned Christ to death after finding no fault in him.

headline: MRS. HALE NOT THE AUTHOR.; Wants the Public to Know She Did Not Write the Novel "My Actor-Husband."
leadPara: I was much distressed to read your criticism of the novel entitled "My Actor-Husband" in THE TIMES of yesterday. I was not annoyed by the vehemence of your attack, for I entirely agree with you, but rather by the aftermath which has come in a flood of protests from friends and casual acquaintances, who infer from your article that the author is myself.

abstract: Roosevelt reaffirms decision to give Massachusetts delegates to Taft

headline: POLO LACKS FEATURES.; H.P. Whitney's Whites Defeat Monte Waterbury's Blues
leadPara: LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 2. -- At the Georgian Court this afternoon there were ten periods of a practice game of polo. The weather was ideal and the ground in excellent condition. headline: AFRAID OF GUFFEY.; Pennsylvania Democrats Appeal to Bryan to Balk Him.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The reorganizing or progressive element in the Pennsylvania Democracy, which defeated the Guffey organization at the primaries, have appealed to William J. Bryan to save them from Guffey at the State Convention, which is to meet next Tuesday. Congresman A. Mitchell Palmer, the progressive leader, professes to have two-thirds of the convention, yet he has asked Mr. Bryan to help him keep Guffey from stealing the National Committeeman.
abstract: Penna Dems ask Bryan aid in balking Guffey faction at state conv

abstract: Rept on sale of J A Harvey collection at Chrystie's

headline: COLONEL IGNORES DELAWARE.; State Having No Primaries, He Declines to Talk Politics.
leadPara: WILMINGTON, Del., May 3. -- Col. Roosevelt refused to make any formal addresses in Delaware to-day. headline: TAFT MEN CONCEDE CLOSE JERSEY VOTE; President Is Weary After Long and Dusty Automobile Trip Through the State.

headline: ROOSEVELT STIRS UP NEW TRUST AGITATION; Congress Fears His Campaign Will Overshadow and Spoil All Its Tariff Work.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The strides made by Col. Roosevelt in his race for the Republican nomination have caused an important readjustment of the legislative programme of both parties in Congress. The Democrats are beginning to fear that in the coming campaign, with Col. Roosevelt at the head of the other party, their year's work here on the tariff will count for nothing.

headline: Manufacturers Make Progressive Strides In General Standardization Work.

headline: ART NOTES FROM LONDON
leadPara: LONDON, June 6. -- The eccentricities of the Italian Futurists, which scored a succes de scandale in London a month or two ago, have at least had one beneficial effect. Things are now accepted, or at least seriously discussed, that only a short while ago would have been dismissed with a shrug or a jeer.

headline: Many of Colonel's Delegates Will Not Follow Him from Convention.; COMPROMISE TALK, TOO
leadPara: CHICAGO, Thursday, June 20, 2 A.M. -- Col. Roosevelt in a belligerent speech before a conference of his delegates early this morning, after the Roosevelt members had quit the Credentials Committee, openly advised a bolt to-day, if the convention should not recede from its stand against his contesting delegates.

headline: ASSAILS CLARK BOOM; TREND TO HARMON; Rivals Say Speaker's Forces Are Honeycombed with Wilson, Harmon, or Foss Sentiment.
leadPara: BALTIMORE, June 19. -- With many of the more important managers of other Democratic candidates for the Presidency on the ground to-day, their followers have been taking a fling at the Clark boom, and have succeeded in creating the impression that the Speaker, although he has the largest number of delegates, has a weaker hold on them than any of the other candidates has on his following.
abstract: Rival mgrs assail Clark

headline: SEES WILSON BEATING TAFT.; Jersey Governor Can Carry Pennsylvania Against President, Says Palmer
leadPara: WASHINGTON, June 19. -- Representative A. Mitchell Palmer of Pennsylvania, who recently defeated James M. Guffey for Democratic National Committeeman from the Keystone State, said to-day that in his opinion the Baltimore convention will realize that the country is thoroughly progressive, and therefore turn to Woodrow Wilson as its candidate.
abstract: Repr A M Palmer sees Wilson able to defeat Taft

headline: RIVAL PLATFORMS ARE NOT FAR APART; Real Radical Planks Are Cut Out of the Roosevelt Document.
leadPara: CHICAGO, June 20. -- The day's work of the Committee on Resolutions makes it more apparent than ever that the fighe between the Roosevelt and Taft factions is entirely personal. The differences between the platforms of the two groups in the committee are practically nil, and each hour's work of revision of the tentative planks prepared in great profusion reduces this difference in style further.
abstract: NY delegation to stick by Barnes; conv unable to get down to business until credentials com completes its work; rule changes affecting Natl Com detailed; resolutions com work shows rival platforms not far apart; some planks noted; permanent orgn com votes to make temporary orgn, including Root chmnship, permanent; other conv developments

headline: CHANGES BY RULES COMMITTEE.; Direct Primary Elections to the National Committee Accepted.
leadPara: CHICAGO, June 20. -- Perpetuation of the so-called "steam roller," so far as the National Committee of the Republican Party is concerned, and recognition of the direct primary plan of electing members of the committee were the two radical and apparently contradictory changes made to-day in the rules governing the National Committee by the Rules Committee of the convention.

headline: ROOSEVELT MISLED ORDERING A BOLT; Called Out Committeemen Under Belief That Gag Rule Had Gone Through.
leadPara: CHICAGO, June 20. -- When the news came that the Roosevelt men had left the meeting of the Committee on Credentials of the Republican National Convention last night, it set the Roosevelt camp in an uproar. The excitement spread throughout the hotels, and everywhere there were knots of yelling and shouting men.
abstract: Roosevelt says he ordered bolt because anon phone call led him to believe credentials com had passed gag rule

headline: WILSON MEN FEAR BOOM FOR GAYNOR; Doubly Active Here as Mayor's Old Political Opponents Praise Him and Get in Line.
leadPara: Supporters of Mayor Gaynor and supporters of Gov. Wilson vied with each other all day yesterday, through press channels and by means of political rumors, to bring their respective candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination into the public eye. When the Gaynor men weren't keeping the newspaper wires busy with "information" there was "news" from Wilson men.

headline: BOLTERS' VOTING ON THE CONTESTS; Colonel's Men Return to Credentials Committee Only to be Beaten, 34 to 15.
leadPara: CHICAGO, June 20. -- Most of the Progressive members of the Committee on Credentials, who bolted from a meeting of that body on orders from Col. Roosevelt late last night, returned to the committee room to-day and took part in the deliberations of that body.

headline: NEARING THE END.
leadPara: Mr. ROOSEVELT will wait until a new party is formed, he will not form one. He will accept the call of the new party if it calls him. How very different is this mood from that in which he burst upon the convention city, all voice, all fight, all bluster, demanding that he be allowed to organize the convention and denouncing as thieves, crooks, thugs, and burglars all who opposed him.

headline: TAFT MEN IN NO HURRY NOW.; Not Considering Hadley as a Candidate -- Hope to Prevent a Split.
FUTILE OBSTINACY.
leadPara: From every point of view except two the opposition which Mr. ROOSEVELT'S followers are making to the organization of the Chicago convention is a sheer barren futility. It does serve the Colonel with a pretext to explain away his defeat. He lacks the manliness to acknowledge that the country has rejected him, that he has been beaten by Mr. TAFT.

headline: TO DECIDE 82 CONTESTS.; Committee Also to Pass on Unit Rule Dispute in Ohio.
leadPara: BALTIMORE, Md., June 21. -- When the National Committee assembles on Monday there will be contests for eighty-two seats for its consideration. This is exclusive of the contention over the votes of the fourteen delegates from Ohio, under the application of the unit rule by the State Central Committee.

headline: CLARK-WILSON MEN SCARED.; But Harmon and Underwood Men Welcome Bryan's Intervention.
leadPara: BALTIMORE, Md., June 21. -- The news that Col. Bryan had telegraphed to Gov. Wilson, Speaker Clark, Gov. Foss, Gov. Burke, Mayor Gaynor, and Gov. Baldwin, asking them to co-operate with him in preventing the selection of Judge Alton B. Parker as Temporary Chairman of the Democratic National Convention, has thrown consternation into the ranks of the supporters of both Speaker Clark and Gov. Wilson.
abstract: urges Clark, Wilson, Foss and others join him in opposing Parker

headline: May Be August Before He Attempts to Launch a New Organization.; AN EYE ON BALTIMORE
leadPara: CHICAGO, June 21. -- With the Roosevelt forces disintegrating like snow before the sun, the managers of President Taft's campaign assert to-night that he will have 700 votes on the first ballot in the Republican National Convention. The Taft forces say they have made steady advances and have gained many recruits during the day, and to-night proclaim the nomination of President Taft on the first ballot to be a foregone conclusion.
abstract: Taft nomination set

headline: FIGHT OUT OF ROOSEVELT MEN.; Only Faint Protests as the Taft Vote in the Convention Grows.
leadPara: CHICAGO, June 21. -- When the Republican National Convention met to-day it was manifest from the outset that the fight was out of it. Throughout the afternoon it ground its way monotonously through the reports of the Committee on Credentials, mechanically voting the Roosevelt men down at every step, without excitement, without interest, and without ginger.

headline: PSYCHOLOGY OF A PEOPLE AS SHOWN IN ELECTIONS
leadPara: NO science in the many which have helped to make modern civilization is more practical and more confused than psychology. Its intimate relation to all sorts of human interests has applied it to every imaginable matter. Before me are two serious articles on the "Psychology of Religious Conversions" and the "Psychology of the Albino Rat"; while two near-serious articles venture the information that "Connie" Mack and Theodore Roosevelt are astute psychologists.

headline: MAY SQUELCH BRYAN LIKE THE COLONEL; Baltimore Delegates in Mood So to Deal with Any Aspirant Who Would Be a Dictator.
leadPara: BALTIMORE, Md., June 22. -- Is Bryan a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination? Can a duck swim? A Philadelphian was overheard this morning saying to himself: "Oh, Bryan will hog it, of course he will. I claim that a yellow dog could be elected now, in view of the scrap at Chicago, though I would prefer a white one."

leadPara: CHICAGO, June 22. -- Amid scenes of turbulence and disorder, which at times bordered upon a riot, the Republican National Convention wound up its labors late to-night by nominating William Howard Taft of Ohio for President and James Schoolcraft Sherman of New York for Vice President.

There is a fight coming on the Philippine tariff, and the wise ones are already trying to anticipate trouble and obtain an agreement locking to harmony. While there is a general trend toward a tariff for revenue only, the exception is the Philippine end.

headline: HARDING NOMINATES TAFT.; Mrs. John A. Logan Leads the Cheering -- Two Delegates Come to Blows.
leadPara: CHICAGO, June 22. -- At exactly 6:10 o'clock this evening Chairman Root of the Republican National Committee nodded to a clerk, who seized a megaphone and bawled to the delegates that the roll of States would be called for the nomination of a candidate for President of the United States. Every State remained silent until Ohio was reached, when announcement was made that that State had a candidate to propose.

headline: DEAN BURGESS OF COLUMBIA REVIEWS AMERICAN EDUCATION
leadPara: AN endowment of $10,000,000 to advance research and original criticism in some existing university -- that is what Dean Burgess, recently retired head of the Graduate Faculties of Columbia University thinks American higher education needs most.

leadPara: LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 22. - W. Campbell Clark is planning for a cruise to East Harbor, Me., early next month on his yacht Mona, one of the largest gasoline-propelled yachts on the Shrewsbury.

leadPara: CHICAGO, June 22. -- Col. Roosevelt has at last openly broken off all connection with the Republican Party as represented in the National Convention.

headline: THE TRIUMPH OF RIGHT.
leadPara: In the nomination of Mr. TAFT the Constitution triumphs, our form of government is vindicated against dangerous assaults, the courts, representative institutions, the guarantees of liberty and property and the orderly administration of law, are safeguarded. President TAFT'S personal victory is notable and great, but he would be the first to protest that it should be held secondary to the triumph of constitutional principles and a government of laws, for that is supreme.

Roosevelt continued at work upon his plans for a progressive party, of which he is to be the leader.

headline: CHEERING CROWDS AT TIMES BULLETINS; Taft and Roosevelt Partisans, and Democrats, Too, in Warm Discussions, but Order Kept.
leadPara: When the nomination of President Taft by the Republican National Convention was bulletined on THE TIMES bulletin board in Times Square last night a few minutes after 10:30 o'clock there was a demonstration which lasted for three minutes. Admirers of the President cheered lustily, while partisans of Col. Roosevelt remained silent.

leadPara: BALTIMORE, June 22. -- The wide-open character of this convention will make it a very different sort of a gathering from that which assembled at Chicago. There were practically only two names cheered there, those of Mr. Taft and Mr. Roosevelt -- with an incidental ovation for Hadley.

leadPara: CHICAGO, June 22. -- The convention started out to-day in good nature, which contrasted strongly with its bitterness and ill-temper in other hours. It kept up that attitude for a while, and was especially inclined to it by the genial fairness of Chairman Root.

Bryan appeared on the car platform the crowd rushed forward and a hundred hands were held out to grasp his.

headline: FIGHT OVER THE CHAIRMANSHIP; Opposition by Bryan Men Greatly Surprises Parker, He Says.
leadPara: BALTIMORE, June 23. -- The fight over the Temporary Chairmanship of the convention has been growing in fury and bitterness all day. It may be disposed of at the meeting of the National Committee to-morrow noon, but if this committee indorses the action of its subcommittee, there will be the hottest kind of a fight on the floor of the convention.

headline: THE PLAIN DUTY OF THE DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION.

headline: ROOSEVELT SEEKS AID OF DEMOCRATS; Progressives of Both Parties to be on His Committee on State Organization.
leadPara: CHICAGO, June 23. -- Col. Theodore Roosevelt's effort to overthrow the Republican Party by forming a Progressive Party, a movement in which he holes the radical members of both the Republican and Democratic organizations will join him, was about the only thing which served to cause even a ripple of excitement here to-day.
abstract: Roosevelt, still in Chicago, maps plans to form Progressive Party; will name both Repubs and Dems to arrangements com; to appt Johnson his field marshal

headline: DEMOCRATS REJOICE AT REPUBLICAN SPLIT; Leaders Now in Baltimore Confident That It Means Victory for the Man They Name.
leadPara: BALTIMORE, June. 23. -- There was an unvarying, note of satisfaction among delegates and thousands of Democrats who are in Baltimore to attend the convention at the prospect afforded by the results of the Chicago Convention. It was the main topic of the day. The Parker incident was for the time dropped as of less importance than the chance to take advantage of the party discomfiture of the Republicans.

headline: CLARK IN LEAD AT START.; Managers Claim 512 Convention Votes and Concede Wilson 180.
leadPara: BALTIMORE, Md., June 23. -- Managers of the various candidates were willing to-day for the first time to give in detail the votes they claim for their men on the first ballot in the Democratic Convention. The aggregate of the claims, of course, totals considerably more than the total number of delegates, which is 1,094.

headline: BASIS OF COL. BRYAN'S CLAIM TO LEADERSHIP; Due to Belief in His Honesty and Courage More Than the Soundness of Hs Principles.
leadPara: BALTIMORE, Md., June 23. -- Why should Mr. Bryan at this particular time project himself into the situation, already difficult enough in all good conscience? is the question many Democrats, without regard to whatever they are conservative or progressive, are asking. Why should he throw his hat into the ring and dare the candidates to take it up?

headline: Point the Sure Way to Democratic Success, They Declare.; WILL NOT ACCEPT PARKER
leadPara: BALTIMORE, Md., June 23. -- The one fact that stands out above all others in the situation here to-night is the agreement of many State leaders already on the ground that this National Democratic Convention must nominate Progressive candidates to run upon a Progressive platform.

headline: BRISTOW IN BALTIMORE.; Progressive Senator Joins Newspaper Corps at Democratic Convention.

leadPara: BALTIMORE, Md., June 24, -- With the Progressives and reactionaries in the Democratic Party apparently as sharply divided on the question of who shall deliver the keynote speech when the Democratic National Convention opens to-morrow as were the Roosevelt and Taft forces at the big Republican show in Chicago, the situation here to-night is charged with political dynamite enough to cause an explosion.
abstract: more prominent Dems express views on candidates and platforms

headline: COMMITTEE UPHOLDS PARKER.; 31 Votes for Him to 20 for Ollie James and 2 for O'Gorman.
leadPara: BALTIMORE, Md., June 24. -- The National Democratic Committee selected ex-Judge Alton B. Parker for Temporary Chairman of the convention at a stormy meeting to-night. Judge Parker got 31 votes, Ollie James of Kentucky got 20, and Senator O'Gorman of New York, who would have been acceptable to the Bryan faction, got 2.

headline: WILSON MEN ATTACK MURPHY AND GAYNOR; The Mayor Termed Evasive on National Questions and Tammany Leadership Scorned.

Murphy.

headline: COULD HAVE WON, ROOSEVELT SAYS; Thirty Southern Delegates Offered to Switch, but He Would Not Stand for Taint.
leadPara: TOLEDO, Ohio, June 24, (On the Twentieth Century Limited with Roosevelt, en route to Oyster Bay.) -- The fight to form a third party is now on in earnest. Today Theodore Roosevelt started back to Oyster Bay to map out his plans, after announcing that the mass convention to nominate him would be held not earlier than three weeks from to-day nor later than six weeks.

headline: NO THIRD PARTY IN KANSAS.; Gov. Stubbs Says One Isn't Needed There, as Roosevelt Will Sweep State.

leadPara: CINCINNATI, .June 24. -- Local men who are leader in the fight be made against the old-line Republican Party by a new organization, at he head of which will be Theodore Roosevelt, say progressive thoughts in Hamilton County, put a new ticket in the field, have an opponent for Congressman Longworth if he doesn't come out publicly for his father-in-law, and carry on a campaign that will make the Republican organization hustle to beat them.

leadPara: BALTIMORE, Md., June 24. -- William Jennings Bryan, backed by the Wilson and other Progressive leaders, is standing against the field to-night on the question whether the Progressives shall organize and run the Democratic National Convention, or whether it shall be opened with a reactionary keynote in an address by ex-Judge Alton B. Parker as Temporary Chairman.

headline: Two Roosevelt Planks.

leadPara: Mr. BRYAN insists that the Baltimore Convention must be Progressive in its platform and in its candidate. Bryan for Temporary Chairman of the Democratic National Convention at the opening session to-day it was generally admitted among the Commoner's friends here that his ante-convention campaign for a Progressive platform and a Progressive candidate -- possibly himself -- had collapsed utterly.

Murphy of New York, Roger Sullivan of Illinois, and Thomas Taggart of Indiana, who have engineered the whole fight against Bryan, have agreed that if they can do so they will line up their forces for a Harmon and Underwood ticket.

At 11 o'clock the seats set apart for delegates and alternates are empty and there are not more than fifty spectators on hand.

headline: CLARK MEN JUBILANT OVER BRYAN'S DEFEAT; Say It Means Speaker's Nomination, Though Some Still Fear Stampede to Nebraskan.
leadPara: BALTIMORE, June 25. -- The managers of all the leading candidates agreed on one thing to-night as the result of the fight over the Temporary Chairmanship in the convention, and that was that Bryan had been eliminated as a possible nominee for President. Whether they spoke for Progressive or reactionary candidates they took the view that Bryan was out of it, and they did not conceal their relief.

headline: CONVENTION BEATS BRYAN, 579 TO 510; PARKER, CHAIRMAN, URGES HARMONY; Nebraskan Fails to Stir the Delegates as of Old.
leadPara: BALTIMORE, June 25. -- William Jennings Bryan made a personal appeal to the Democratic National Convention at its first session to-day to make him its Temporary Chairman instead of Judge Alton B. Parker of New York, whom he designated as the candidate of the "predatory Wall Street interests."

headline: CERTAIN BRYAN ERRORS.
leadPara: It would be better for Mr. BRYAN if he would refrain from saying so many things that are not so. He charged that Judge PARKER was but a tool of Wall Street, a representative of the predatory interests, who in Baltimore were "more brazenly at work than they were at Chicago."

headline: Flinn's Organization Split.
leadPara: PITTSBURGH, Penn., June 25. -- It looks now as though the Flinn-Magee political organization, which was swept into power on the Roosevelt wave at the primaries, is going to split on the rocks of dissension. Flinn returned to his office to-day for the first time since June 4, when he went to Chicago to put the fear of Roosevelt into the National Committee.

headline: BALTIMORE OUTLOOK PLEASES ROOSEVELT; Quite Satisfied There'll Be No Truce with Bryan, and Situation Is Like That in Chicago.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, N.Y., June 25. -- Col. Roosevelt and those who are supporting him in his attempt to form a third party are anxiously awaiting the action taken by the Democratic National Convention at Baltimore, and the conference of Roosevelt leaders, which had at first been planned for late this week, will be delayed until after the Democratic nominations have been made.

headline: CONVENTION SMASHES THE UNIT RULE; GREAT DEMONSTRATION FOR WILSON; Delegates Cheer 31 Minutes for the New Jersey Governor.
leadPara: BALTIMORE, Md., June 26. -- Following a remarkable outburst of enthusiasm for Gov. Wilson in the Democratic convention to-night, the delegates voted, 565 1/2 to 491 1-3 against the unit rule. This was a victory for the Wilson supporters, and led to another demonstration for the New Jersey Governor.

headline: PLATFORM AND CANDIDATE.

leadPara: BALTIMORE, June 29. -- Though the ninth session of the Democratic Convention, which was called to order shortly after 1 o'clock this afternoon, was destined to furnish material for a red letter chapter in Democratic Party history, it began its real business of nominating a candidate for President in a very quiet and orderly fashion by calling the roll of States on the thirteenth ballot.

headline: 200 ROOSEVELT MEN BOLT.; And Form Progressive Party in Bay State -- Chicago Delegates Stay Regular.
leadPara: BOSTON, June 29. -- Two hundred Republicans who were active in the Roosevelt campaign bolted the Republican Party at a meeting in Fordham this afternoon and formed "The Progressive Party in Massachusetts."

headline: NO LET-UP IN TRADE; Advices from Leading Cities Are of Growing Optimism Among Business Men.
leadPara: Advices to the mercantile agencies from the leading cities of the country tell of continued optimism nearly everywhere, and trade statistics bear out the general impression of growing trade. Outside New York, where the exchanges of checks among banks are not so directly influenced by stock market operations, there is a good increase in clearings.

headline: PROGRESSIVES START STATE ORGANIZATION; Amos Pinchot, Linden Bates, Jr., and 300 Others Denounce Taft in Resolutions.
leadPara: A State organization of the Progressive Party was started with much enthusiasm last night in Terrace Garden. It was named the New York State Roosevelt League. Lindon Bates, Jr., former Assemblyman, who a few days ago resigned as Chairman of the Campaign Committee of the New York Republican Club, presided at the meeting, and Amos Pinchot was the chief spokesman.

Crane called on him last Tuesday, by virtually announcing his intention to bolt the Democratic ticket if a Ryan-Belmont or Wall-Street-controlled candidate for the Presidency were nominated by this convention.

Woodrow Wilson of New Jersey as the Democratic candidate for President came as a distinct relief to representatives of every faction in Washington, with the possible exception of a few of the Speaker's close personal friends, who think that the convention having given Mr. Clark a majority on eight ballots really owed him the nomination.

headline: WILSON MEN ALWAYS CERTAIN OF VICTORY; Though Some of His Opponents Said He Couldn't Win Up to the Last Moment.
leadPara: BALTIMORE, Md., July 2. -- A victory for progressibe Democracy. Thus was summed up by the leading factors in this Democratic National Convention destined to go down in history as one of the most important of party gatherings in a century, the result that was attained with the nomination for President of Gov. Woodrow Wilson of New Jersey.

headline: WOODROW WILSON FOR PRESIDENT
leadPara: In the nomination of WOODROW WILSON the Democratic Party regains its ancient estate of worth, of dignity, of power. It escapes the thralldom of little men and ignoble leaders. It takes as its chief a man of that statesmanlike quality which befits the Presidential office.
abstract: Editorial lauding Wilson nomination

headline: Wilson the Strongest Man.
GOV. WILSON NOT ELATED BY VICTORY; Feels the Tremendous Responsibility Even More Than Honor of the Nomination.

headline: GOV. DIX DELIGHTED BY CHOICE OF WILSON; He Says Party Differences Have Been Settled and Democratic Victory Is Certain.
leadPara: Some of the delegates to the Democratic National Convention and some of those who went down there to cheer on the work and the workers returned to this city last night. Among those who got in on the Pennsylvania's Washington Express was Congressman Martin W. Littleton.

headline: MISSOURIANS ALL FOR HIM.; Say He Will Win Progressives and Check Roosevelt.
leadPara: ST. LOUIS, July 2. -- That the selection of Gov. Wilson was a wise choice, and that he will lead the party to victory in November, was the unanimous opinion expressed here by leading Democrats. They believe that he will draw to his support thousands of progressive Republicans who have forsaken Taft.

headline: Indiana Governor Is Named for Vice President at 1:56 A.M.; TWO BALLOTS WERE TAKEN
leadPara: BALTIMORE, Md., Wednesday, July 3. -- Gov. Thomas R. Marshall of Indiana was nominated for Vice President by the Democratic Convention at 1:56 o'clock this morning, and the convention adjourned. The nomination was made by acclamation after two ballots had been taken.

headline: BIG DEMONSTRATION AT TIMES BULLETINS; Streetful of Men and Women Cheer Wilson for 10 Minutes on Nomination.
leadPara: It the general opinion among watchers of THE TIMES'S bulletin boards yesterday, that the nomination of Woodrow Wilson for President by the Democratic convention at Baltimore means the collapse of the Roosevelt third party movement.

headline: NOMINATE TAFT MAN FOR OHIO GOVERNOR; Judge E.B. Dillon Chosen Over Roosevelt Candidate by Majority of 100.
leadPara: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 2. -- Taft delegates who controlled the first session of the Republican State Convention three weeks ago by a majority of only 28 1/2, came back to-day, and by a majority of more than 100 defeated an anti-Taft candidate for Governor and adopted a platform approving the Chicago platform and warmly commending the Administration of President Taft.
abstract: Repub state conv opens, Columbus; nominates Judge E B Dillon for Gov; adopts platform; full election ticket listed

headline: THE PRESS OF THE COUNTRY.
HOW THE PRIMARIES WORKED.
leadPara: It is Mr. WORKS, a California Progressive, who moves for a Senatorial investigation of the working of the Presidential preference primaries. If the Progressives are disappointed in the working of their scheme, others may be pardoned for feeling the same sentiment even more strongly.
abstract: ed on how Pres primaries work

headline: CHOICE OF WILSON DELIGHTS LEADERS; Will Unify Party, Say Philadelphia Democrats -- Progressives Frankly Praise It.
leadPara: PHILADELPHIA, July 2. -- Wilson's nomination was received by Democrats in this city with great enthusiasm. Men of the "old guard," as well as the Progressive Democrats, declared that the work of the Baltimore convention had united the party, and that for the first time in years the party would make a strong fight against the opposing tickets.

headline: ROOSEVELT GOES ON WITH A THIRD TICKET; Result at Baltimore Makes New Party All the More Necessary, He Declares.

headline: ROOSEVELT TO RUN, ANYWAY.; Admits an Uphill Fight -- Says He Didn't Expect Gov. Osborn to Stick.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, N.Y., July 3. -- There was a serious conference at Sagamore Hill late this afternoon between Col. Roosevelt, George W. Perkins, Frank A. Munsey, ex-Senator Flinn of Pittsburgh, Senator Dixon, the Roosevelt campaign manager, and E.A. Van Valkenburg. At its conclusion Col. Roosevelt again declared there was no thought of giving up the fight, and that he would certainly accept the nomination of the Progressives and battle on to the end.
abstract: Prendergast says 3d party plans are unaffected by Gov Wilson nomination for US Pres

headline: MANY DESERTING ROOSEVELT RANKS; Progressive Leaders Throughout the Country Refuse to Go on with Third Party.
leadPara: Progressive leaders in many parts of the country have notified Col. Theodore Roosevelt that they will no longer follow him as the candidate of a third political party. They take the stand that the nomination of Gov. Woodrow Wilson for President by the Democrats makes Col. Roosevelt's election impossible and his race for the office therefore a useless one.
abstract: Many progressive leaders deserting Roosevelt

leadPara: SEA GIRT, N.J., July 3. -- Telegrams of congratulation continued to flood the telegraph wires leading into Sea Girt to-day until the total reached nearly 5,000. The mails brought almost as many letters as there were telegrams, and three stenographers were kept busy sorting out and arranging the messages in groups.

headline: THIRD PARTY IN INDIANA.; Progressive Republicans Meet Preliminary to a State Convention.
FINANCIAL MARKETS; Stocks Close at Net Gain After Sharp Reaction -- The Banks' Loss of Cash.
leadPara: After confused price movements the general level of quotations at the end of the Stock Exchange session yesterday was slightly higher than at the close of the previous day. This improvement was, so to speak, an afterthought, for it came after a decline which carried stocks rather sharply downward from the opening figures, which represented some overnight advance.

headline: Against Colorado Third Party.
leadPara: COLORADO SPRINGS, July 3. -- The stand taken by Philip B. Stewart in refusing to join the Third Party movement as distinct from the regular Republican organization in this State was vindicated by a large majority of Progressives from all parts of Colorado, who attended a conference here yesterday and last night, and decided to make the fight within the ranks and overthrow the old party bosses, if possible.

headline: Ohio Men Quit Roosevelt.
leadPara: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 3. -- The third party movement will receive no support in Ohio from Walter L. Brown, Arthur I. Garford, and D. Mead Massie, the Roosevelt leaders in the State. They said to-day that they were satisfied with the nomination of Judge Dillon for Governor, and that they would support him.

headline: THAW IS INCURABLE, SAYS DR. MACDONALD; Noted Alienist Testifies That Prisoner's Insane Delusions Are Typical of Paranoia.

headline: KEYSTONE SWING TO TAFT.; Pittsburgh Mayor to Line Up Machine for Him -- Wasson Quits Flinn.
WILSON WON'T RESIGN AT ONCE; To Do So Would Be to Turn the State Government Over to the Republican Machine.
leadPara: SEA GIRT, N.J., July 3. -- This has been a field day for friends, neighbors, and hand-shaking enthusiasts, who have swarmed around Gov. Woodrow Wilson. To-morrow, with the arrival of the Democratic National Committee from the convention city the serious work of mapping out the Democratic National campaign will be undertaken, and receptions to local friends of the candidate naturally will be subordinated.
abstract: Wilson will not resign as Gov at once because it would mean turning State Govt over to Repub machine

headline: THIRD PARTY RANKS BREAKING TO WILSON; Progressives of Pennsylvania Will Support Democratic Candidate.
leadPara: CHICAGO, Ill., July 4. -- The third party sentiment is on the wane in Illinois, and since the nomination of Woodrow Wilson at Baltimore, the new Roosevelt headquarters at the Congress Hotel have been deserted. Among even the most rabid supporters of Roosevelt, it is admitted that there is little chance of the third party polling an appreciable vote in Illinois in November.

headline: Sin of Weakness in Philadelphia.
Michigan Progressives for Wilson.
leadPara: DETROIT, Mich., July 4. -- A meeting of Progressive Republican leaders will be held in Lansing to-morrow to take the first steps toward putting into the field a complete State ticket and county ticket for the Fall election. No presidential electors will be nominated, as the plan is to vote for Wilson as a surer way of carrying the State against Taft. There are two candidates for United States Senator against William Alden Smith.

headline: HOW THE GIRLS VOTED.; Junior Republic's Radical Leader Found Them Emotional and 'Grafters'
leadPara: During my "career" in the Junior Republic at Freeville, N.Y., I was the founder and a leader of "The Progressive Party," which came into being as a revolt against the "old" or "conservative order of things." I was always a radical and every measure I supported was radical. I found that the more radical the measure the more support could I count on from the girls.

headline: ROOSEVELT TACKLES HIGH COST OF LIVING; Thinks Democratic and Republican Platforms Neglected It, and He'll Make It the Issue.
Pittsburgh Progressives for Wilson.
OSBORN ASKS WILSON VOTES.; Michigan Governor Says It Is Only Way to Defeat Reactionaries.
A REPUBLICAN ISSUE.
leadPara: In the waning days of Congress the Republicans of the Senate have kindly come to the aid of tariff reform, though they did not intend to lend a hand. To every measure for the reduction of high protective duties they have offered, or made it plain that they would offer, amendments restoring the duty on paper and repealing the act for reciprocity with Canada.

headline: St. Louis Republicans in a Row.
leadPara: ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 5. -- The meeting of Republicans for the purpose of launching a Progressive Republican movement in St. Louis broke up in a near riot to-night, when several Taft speakers attempted to plead for harmony and the straight Republican ticket.

headline: BRYAN TALKS OF TICKET.; Says Champ Clark Virtually Threw His Chances Away.

headline: Hadley Against Third Party.

CUMMINS DECLINES TO JOIN NEW PARTY; Iowa Senator, Himself a Candidate in Chicago, Denounces Roosevelt's Plan.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, July 5. -- Senator Cummins of Iowa to-day joined the long list of prominent Progressives who have denounced Col. Roosevelt's new party plan. Mr. Cummins was himself a candidate for President before the Chicago Convention, but he has always been counted a Roosevelt man.

headline: AGAIN CHALLENGES COLONEL.; La Follette Repeats Request That Roosevelt Disclose Campaign Funds.
leadPara: MADISON, Wis., July 5. -- United States Senator La Follette in an article to-day in his weekly paper, asks Col. Roosevelt for the second time to publish his expense account, or else "a candid statement of his reasons for thus spurning one of the basic principles of public morality and political decency."
abstract: La Follette again challenges Roosevelt to disclose data on his '12 campaign funds, article in State Journal

headline: WILSON CONSULTS O'GORMAN AS LEADER; Senator from New York Has a Long Conference with Him at Sea Girt and Offers Advice.
leadPara: SEA GIRT, N.J., July 5. -- In carrying out his announced policy of consulting with prominent Democratic leaders from all sections of the country before announcing final decision as to the plan and scope of the National Democratic campaign and the personnel of the Campaign Committee, Gov. Woodrow Wilson invited United States Senator James A. O'Gorman of New York to Sea Girt this evening for dinner and a long confidential conference.
abstract: Wilson says Dem platform meets cost-of-living issue

headline: NOT A "THIRD TICKET."; Plan of New Party to Capture Regular Organization In Many States.
leadPara: The effect of Mr. Roosevelt's nomination by the new Progressive Party would not be, as some think, to put Col. Roosevelt on a "third ticket." In the States of Maine, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Illinois, Minnesota, South Dakota, Kansas, Nebraska, Oklahoma, California, Idaho, Washington, Oregon, Missouri, Wisconsin, North Dakota, and West Virginia, the Progressives are in control of the party organization and have controlled the primaries by an overwhelming vote.

headline: Article 2 -- No Title
leadPara: WASHINGTON, D.C., July 5. -- The Roosevelt convention will be held in Chicago about Aug. 10, according to a telegram received here to-day from Senator Dixon. The telegram was addressed to a member of the Roosevelt provisional committee. An interesting point is that the telegram, informs the one to whom it is addressed that his name will he signed to the formal call, unless he wires objection.

headline: THIRD PARTY MEN HINT AT SURPRISE; It Is to Come In a Statement Which the Colonel Has in His Hands for Supervision.
leadPara: Col. Roosevelt's third party movement may not be making as much noise as might be expected of it, but there is Senator Dixon's word for it that something will happen to-day which will make both the old parties take notice.

headline: La Follette Favors Wilson.
leadPara: MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 5. -- La Follette's Wisconsin followers are adopting the attitude of the State Journal, La Follette's supposed daily newspaper organ, in declaring for Wilson for President, but for progressive Republicans for State and Congressional offices.

headline: Roosevelt Worker Deserts.
leadPara: BOSTON, July 5. -- The bandana party got a severe setback to-day when Charles L. Burrill, a banker, who was a prominent Roosevelt worker in the nomination campaign, to-day backed away from the opportunity to be a State Committeeman in the proposed third party. He wrote a letter to that effect to the Progressive party Secretary saying he has never been out of the Republican Party.
abstract: C L Burrill deserts Roosevelt

headline: NAMES MICHIGAN CHIEFS.; Roosevelt and Dixon Select Men to Head New State Ticket.
leadPara: LANSING, Mich., July 6. -- Sybrant Wesselius of Grand Rapids, who was the right-hand man of Gov. Hazen S. Pingree in the original Progressive movement in Michigan, and Theodore M. Joslin, Mayor of Adrian, who is the Progressive candidate for United States Senator against William Alden Smith, have been selected by Col. Roosevelt and Senator Dixon as the heads of the Progressive movement in Michigan since the defection of Gov. Osborn.

National Reliability Tour Committee includes Col. Frank M. Joyce of Minneapolis, Lewis R. Speare of Boston, John A. Wilson of Franklin, Penn., W.E. Metzger of Detroit, and W.E. Moyer of Des Moines.

leadPara: THAT Grover Cleveland possessed a most acute sense of fairness as well as a consientious regard for duty was accentuated very early in his public career by a painful incident.

leadPara: THE holding of the Olympic games this season in Sweden is made the occasion by G.P. Putnam's Sons, acting as agents for the Cambridge University Press, for the publication of a volume in which various social and religious customs of the Greeks are described and traced to their origin.

headline: Georgia Men Are Busy.
leadPara: ATLANTA, Ga., July 6. -- The friends of Col. Roosevelt in Georgia are rapidly go ing ahead with the movement for the organization of a new party. The Roosevelt Progressive League of Georgia, which has been in existence for some time, is doing the organization work necessary to launch the new party.

The statement was considered necessary by the Speaker and the Missouri delegation in Congress because of a rumor that Taft Democratic clubs were to be organized in Missouri.

headline: OLD PARTIES DOOMED, SAYS VICTOR BERGER; Time Coming When There Will Be a Straight Line-Up Between Conservatives and Radicals. SOCIALISTS TO PROFIT BY IT Predicts They Will Poll 2,000,000 Votes -- Roosevelt Heading "Nowhere in Particular."
leadPara: WASHINGTON, July 7. -- Victor L. Berger of Milwaukee, the only Socialist Member of Congress, gave THE NEW YORK TIMES an interview to-day on the present political situation and the work of the Baltimore and Chicago conventions. Roosevelt and his managers are planning an aggressive campaign, in which Roosevelt expects to lead and force the other candidates to follow in bringing forward the Progressive issues.

Wilson this afternoon all of New Jersey's delegates to the Baltimore convention except former Senator James Smith, Jr., all of the alternates, including the alternate for Mr. Smith, and about every one residing along the Jersey coast who has any interest in political affairs.

Roosevelt spent most of his time to-day in New York with his leaders, discussing details of his camaign in New York State, and also attempting to decide upon some system for the selection of delegates to the Progressive National Convention, which is to be held in Chicago on Aug. 5.

Fairchild of Kansas for the office are straining every effort to capture sufficient votes to insure the choice of their candidate to-morrow morning.
