headline: NON-SECTIONAL, SAYS COLONEL.; Progressives Appeal to the Blue and Gray, a Common Heritage.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, N.Y., July 12. -- Col. Roosevelt declared to-night that the Progressive movement was a non-sectional one. He refused to make any direct comment on the address of Gen. Daniel Sickles yesterday at a gathering of the third party advocates in New York, when Sickles said that Gov. Wilson should not be elected President because he was a born Southerner.
abstract: Roosevelt says progressive movement is non-sectional, int, Oyster Bay

headline: COL. REEDY OF MISSOURI PREDICTS WILSON VICTORY; St. Louis Editor Who Knows What Is Going On Feels' Democratic Success in His Bones.
abstract: article on Col W M Reedy, St Louis ed, prediction of Wilson victory

headline: Bull Moose Call in Nevada.
THE PROHIBITION TICKET.; Eugene W. Chafin for President and A.S. Watkins for Vice President.
leadPara: ATLANTIC CITY, July 12. -- The National Prohibition Party adjourned its three days' National Convention here this evening after nominating as the standard bearers for the next election the two men whose names headed the ticket four years ago. These men were Eugene W. Chaflin of Arizona for President and Aaron S. Watkins of Ohio for Vice President.
abstract: Prohibition Party conv nominates E W Chafin for Pres, A S Watkins for Vice Pres

headline: EMPIRE DEMOCRACY TO COMBAT MURPHY; Independents Organize It to End His Control and to Carry State for Wilson.
leadPara: A new insurgent movement is about to be started in the Democratic Party in this State. Senator Franklin D. Roosevelt, who won fame as leader of the insurgents who defeated Tammany Leader Charles F. Murphy in his purpose to send William F. Sheehan to the United States Senate, is its moving spirit.
abstract: New orgn to be called Empire State Democracy proposed by Sen F D Roosevelt and other Dem insurgents to combat Murphy control

headline: M'COMBS CHOSEN FOR NATIONAL CHAIRMAN; Gov. Wilson Has Not Announced It, but Hudspeth Lets It Be Inferred.
leadPara: SEA GIRT, N.J., July 12. -- From the front door of Gov. Woodrow Wilson's Summer home here three men emerged together this afternoon, one of them showing a slight limp, and all three appearing very solemn. Many personal and political friends of Gov. Wilson were assembled on the lawn outside.
abstract: other rumors from Sea Girt

headline: New Orleans's Filtered Water.
FLINN'S PLAN FOR ELECTORS.; Taft and Third Party to Nominate the Same Set in Pennsylvania.
leadPara: PHILADELPHIA, July 13. -- After an all-day conference here between ex-Senator William Flinn and the supporters of Col. Roosevelt from the eastern counties of Pennsylvania to consider the organization of the third party in this State, it was announced that the conferrees favored the placing of the same set of Presidential Electors on both the Re publican and third party tickets.

headline: DEMOCRATS FOR PROGRESSIVES.; Geneva Wilson Club Hears Call for New Ideas in State Campaign.
LA FOLLETTE LEADER TO AID WILSON CAUSE; C.R. Crane of Wisconsin Says He Will Contribute Freely if Governor Will Let Him.
leadPara: SEA GIRT, N.J., July 13. -- In a series of intimate interviews with political leaders known in all parts of the country Gov. Woodrow Wilson made more progress to-day in sketching the outlines of his approaching campaign for the Presidency than in all the previous days since he received the nomination at Baltimore.
abstract: Wilson conf with Clark, other pol leaders at Sea Girt; details; La Follette backer C R Crane offers Wilson financial support

headline: CAMPAIGN BRINGS YOUNG MEN TO THE FRONT AS LEADERS; Some of Those, Unknown Four Years Ago, Who Have Jumped Into Fame and Become Factors in National Affairs.
leadPara: NEARLY every National campaign brings out a young man or two as a National figure never heard of before. He takes the skyrocket route to fame; only he doesn't burst in one brilliant glow. The glow sometimes lasts for a lifetime. The young man in politics is as old as the bills.

headline: Article 1 -- No Title
leadPara: PITTSBURGH, Penn., July 13. -- The Progressive Party of Pennsylvania was organized here to-day at the Headquarters of the Keystone Party. Clarence V. Tiers was elected State Chairman, and announced that the Progressives intended to fuse with the Keystoners and with the Democrats in the Congressional and legislative fights.

headline: ROOSEVELT SAYS HE HAD LORIMER OUSTED; The Matter Would Have Been Dropped if He Had Not Refused to Sit at Table with Him.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, N.Y., July 13. -- Col. Roosevelt was immensely pleased this afternoon when he heard of the vote in the Lorimer case.

headline: WHIST CONGRESS ENDS.; Prize Winners Announced in Various Styles of Competition.
leadPara: The twenty-second annual congress of the American Whist League came to an end Saturday evening with these results:

headline: TAFT MEN HOLD MONTCLAIR.; In a Test Vote of General Committee He Wins, 18 to 4.
abstract: Taft men hold control of Montclair, NJ, Repub gen com

headline: WISCONSIN MEN SEE COLONEL.; Cochems and Van Hise Discuss Campaign Issues with Him.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, July 14. -- Col. Roosevelt conferred to-day with Charles R. Van Hise, President of Wisconsin University, and Harry Cochems, who led the Wisconsin delegation at the Republican National Convention at Chicago, and resigned because, he said, Senator La Follette was determined to beat Roosevelt at all costs.

headline: POLITICS IN ILLINOIS IN MUDDLED CONDITION; Medill McCormick Has Hopes for Bull Moose Party, But Deneen's Attitude Is Puzzling.
leadPara: CHICAGO, July 14. -- In spite of his Presbyterian training, which forbids the worshipping of images, Medill McCormick is still bowing down to stocks and stones.
abstract: article on 3d party movement led by McCormick in Illinois

headline: WORKING TO FORM THIRD PARTY HERE; Provisional County Chairmen Named in Move to Pick Delegates for Chicago Convention.
leadPara: Temporary State Chairman Hotchkiss of the Progressive Party outlined yesterday the way in which the work of completing the temporary organization of the Roosevelt political forces was being effected.
abstract: Progressive Party temporary chmn Hotchkiss outlines way in which work of completing temporary orgn of Roosevelt forces is being effected

headline: STOKES FOR COMPROMISE, TOO.; Sticks to His Party, but Willing to Let Popular Vote Decide.
leadPara: TRENTON, N.J., July 15. -- Former Gov. E.C. Stokes, who was one of the first New Jersey Republican leaders to support the candidacy of Theodore Roosevelt for the Presidential nomination, issued a statement to-day in which he sets forth his own position in the coming fight.

headline: McCORMICK TELLS WHY HE IS AGAINST TAFT; Head of the Bull Moose Party in Illinois Gives His Reasons for His Activity for Roosevelt.
leadPara: CHICAGO, July 14. -- As previously noted, Medill McCormick is the head and front of the Bull Moose movement in Illinois. He is Chairman of the Illinois Committee, or man of all work, at least, charged with the hard task of changing the political status of this State and recanting the beliefs of a lifetime.
abstract: article on McCormick reasons for opposing Taft and banking Roosevelt

headline: SENATOR WORKS HAS NEW IDEA; No Republican Candidate, He Says, and Electors Could Vote for Wilson.
C.R. CRANE LAUDS WILSON.; Most Desirable Candidate for President Since Cleveland, He Says.
ROOSEVELT NEAR BREAK WITH AIDS; Emphatic in Opposing the Pennsylvania and Maryland Compromise Plans.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 15. -- An open breach between Col. Roosevelt and some of his leaders seems likely to develop as a result of the compromise plans made by Republicans in Pennsylvania and Maryland, who cast their lot with the third party, to save their State tickets and State organizations. Col. Roosevelt sees trouble ahead, and the situation is giving him some alarm.
abstract: Roosevelt and some leaders near breach over Penna and Maryland compromise plan

headline: CONGRESSMEN FEAR ROOSEVELT CAMPAIGN; Even the Colonel's Own Followers Hope to Get on the Taft Ticket, Too.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, July 15. -- An extraordinary effect of the split in the Republican Party that Col. Roosevelt is working hard to effect throughout the country is the reuniting of the party ranks in Congress. In the Senate on the two last tariff roll calls the insurgents and regulars voted solidly together, and in the House the same thing may be seen.
abstract: Repub Congressmen acting to keep Dem Party from benefitting from expected splits among Repubs; many Roosevelt followers hope to get on Taft ticket; Taft to be officially notified of nomination Aug 1st; Underwood and Wilson comment on Dem tariff plank; other campaign news

headline: SMITH QUITS TO AID ROOSEVELT CAMPAIGN; Commissioner of Corporations Declares New Party Meets His Ideas.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Herbert Knox Smith resigned to-day as Commissioner of Corporations to join the forces of Theodore Roosevelt and the new Progressive Party. He will be succeeded, in all probability, by Luther Conant, Jr., of Brooklyn, N.Y., the present Deputy Commissioner of Corporations, who is described as an Administration exponent.
abstract: Smith resigns as US Comr of Corps to aid Roosevelt campaign

headline: DEMOCRATS GREET MARSHALL; Committeemen Pledge Loyal to Vice Presidential Candidate.
leadPara: INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 16. -- Thomas R. Marshall, Democratic candidate for Vice President, received to-day at the State Capitol twenty members of the Democratic National Committee, who at the invitation of Thomas Taggart, commiteeman from Indiana, had stopped in this city on their way from the reorganization meeting at Chicago.
abstract: Marshall receives Dem Natl Com members, Indianapolis

headline: COLONEL WILL AVOID SPECIALS.; Talks with Perkins and Decides to Travel Mostly on Regular Trains.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, N.Y., July 16. -- If any progress was made toward smoothing over the threatened breach between Col. Roosevelt and some of his leaders because of the compromise proposals in Pennsylvania and Maryland, there was no indication of it to-day. To-night Col. Roosevelt still clung to the position he took yesterday in his statement, in which he said that he would not agree to anything bordering on a compromise with the Taft forces.
abstract: conf with Perkins on details of Western primary campaign

headline: This One Writes He Is for Wilson and Not Roosevelt.
VAN VALKENBURG EXPLAINS.; Flinn's Electoral Plan Meant to Benefit the Colonel, He Says.
leadPara: PHILADELPHIA, July 16. -- E.A. Van Valkenburg, one of the Pennsylvania signers of the call for a Progressive Party National Convention, gave out a statement to-day explaining the meaning of the plan as announced by ex-Senator William Flinn to have the same Presidential Electors on both the Taft and Roosevelt tickets. Col. Roosevelt came out vigorously against this plan yesterday.
abstract: Van Valkenburg explains meaning of Flinn plan to have same Pres electors on both Taft and Roosevelt tickets

headline: ROOSEVELT QUITS REPUBLICAN CLUB; Makes No Comment, but Resigns by Letter, Which Takes the Regular Course.
leadPara: One by one Col. Theodore Roosevelt is burning all thee bridges between himself and the Republican Party. Yesterday he sent a letter to the Republican Club tendering his resignation as a member. The epistle was curt and to the point. It was directed to J. Van Vechten Olcott, President of the club, and read:
abstract: Roosevelt resigns as member of Repub Club, NYC

headline: THOSE PRINCIPLES.
leadPara: Mr. HERBERT KNOX SMITH, in resigning the office of Commissioner of Corporations, frankly told the President that he resigned in order to join "the new Progressive Party." The progressive movement, he added, "in''cludes principles that I believe in, "and that I have earnestly tried to "further, so far as I could, during my "term of Federal service.
abstract: ed on Smith reasons for resigning

headline: ROOSEVELT GIVES UP TRIP.; Induced by Managers Not to Stump Till After Convention.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, N.Y., July 17. -- Col. Roosevelt has decided to abandon his Western primary campaign, which he had planned to make before the convention of Progressives at Chicago on Aug. 5. This announcement was made late to-night by O.K. Davis, head of the Roosevelt Publicity Bureau, after a long conference at Sagamore Hill, attended by Senator Dixon and George W. Perkins.
abstract: Dixon predicts Roosevelt will beat Wilson and Taft will not get an electoral vote

headline: $20 A SEAT TO SEE ROOSEVELT NAMED; That's the Price for Front Rows at the Progressives' Convention, Chicago, on Aug. 5.
leadPara: CHICAGO, July 17 -- Members of the local Committee on Arrangements decided to-day to hold the Progressive Party's National Convention at the Coliseum on Aug. 5 instead of the Auditorium, the place first selected. The change was made in order to provide more seats for spectators.
abstract: conv to be held at Chicago Coliseum and expenses will be met by selling tickets to spectators; C E Merriam explains his refusal to join party, statement

headline: OPPOSES ROOSEVELT TICKET.; His Michigan Chairman Will Seek Office as a Republican Nominee.
DEMOCRATS ARE UNITED.; Split In Pennsylvania Central Committee is Healed.
1908 STEAM ROLLER UNKNOWN TO COLONEL; He Had Known of It, He Says, and Its Practices, He Would Have Stopped It.
leadPara: Col. Theodore Roosevelt, while he dwelt in the White House, in one of his messages to Congress reviled men "with soft hands and hard faces." In an editorial in the current weekly issue of The Outlook he goes a step further and vigorously assails as enemies of social and economic justice "men who live softly."
abstract: contrasts Chicago and Baltimore convs and results of each

headline: THIRD PARTY LEADERS FEW AT OYSTER BAY; Scarcely Any Political Powers Among Everyday Visitors Now and Roosevelt Seems Worried.
abstract: Roosevelt cancellation of Western primary trip seen affecting 3d party movement

headline: DIX DEFINES PROGRESSIVE.; Sure He Is One Because He Turned a Deficit Into a Surplus.
abstract: Dix gives his definition of a progressive

headline: GOV. MARSHALL PUTS TARIFF ISSUE FIRST; Vice Presidential Nominee Says Protection Is Unconstitutional and Should Be Destroyed.
leadPara: INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 19. -- Abraham Lincoln, unlike his latest reincarnation, always said something worth saying. For example, when he was in this town on Feb. 11, 1861, on his way to Washington to assume the Presidency, he made a speech from which these words are preserved on a bronze plate fixed into the wall of the Claypool:
abstract: Editorial on Repub Party's 2 lines of campaigning

headline: PROGRESSIVE PLANS UPSET.; Washington State Law Makes Full Separate Tickets Necessary.
FORM PARTY UNDER OAKS.; Progressives of Michigan to Begin Fight Where Republicans First Met.
TO URGE TAFT CAUSE BEFORE C0NGRESS; Speeches Defending Method of Chicago Nomination to be Made in Both Branches.
abstract: Taft thanks Negro delegates for support at conv, s to Natl Civil & Pol Negro League at White House

headline: Article 15 -- No Title
VISIT TO ROOSEVELT CASTS DOWN LEADERS; Jerseymen Go Away Moody and the Colonel Again Declares Against Compromise.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, N.Y., July 20. -- Developments to-day served rather to broaden than heal over what seems here to be the impending break in the third party. Leaders from New Jersey and the New England States, who came to Sagamore Hill, went away in no pleasant mood, and when Col. Roosevelt was seen later he was aggressive.
abstract: Leaders from NJ and New Eng visit Roosevelt; seem dissatisfied; Roosevelt again declares against compromise; Smith meets with Roosevelt; other developments

headline: WISCONSIN TO SELL LIFE INSURANCE -- SOON; Policies May Range from $500 to $3,000, with Premiums Little Less Than Private Rates.
abstract: Wisconsin to sell life ins with premiums slightly lower than private cos rates; officials deny plan is Socialistic

headline: SOCIETY CIRCUS AT SEA GATE; Atlantic Yacht Club Members Appear as "Wonderful" Animals.
leadPara: Two performances of a society circus were given yesterday by the Atlantic Yacht Club at Sea Gate. The show took place in a tent erected alongside the clubhouse. Members of the club to the number of fifty appeared in the garb of clowns, and there were twenty-eight acts, some of them by professionals.
abstract: hon at dinner by United Syrian Soc NYC

headline: TO NATIONALIZE TENNIS.; President Wrenn Hopes to Have All Players Registered.
leadPara: Robert D. Wrenn, President of the United States National Lawn Tennis Association, sounded the first note in the progressive movement toward the nationalizing of the game at a meeting of the Ranking Committee held yesterday at the office of George T. Adee at 38 Broad Street.

headline: WILSON'S ADVISERS GOOD FIGHTERS ALL; Intimate Sketches of the Men Who Are to Direct the Democratic Campaign.
leadPara: Gov. Woodrow Wilson of New Jersey, the Democratic nominee for President, upset party political traditions of a generation on Thursday when he named as an Advisory Committee to aid in his election fourteen men, the majority of whom are almost unknown outside of their individual States, but who from now on will have a large voice in directing the destinies of the Democratic Party.

headline: MICHIGAN TO HAVE FULL THIRD TICKET; Progressives, in State Convention, Cut Loose from Republicans at Roosevelt's Request.
leadPara: JACKSON, Mich., July 20. -- The Progressives of Michigan met here in convention to-day, got orders from Col. Roosevelt through the person of Senator Dixon, to put a full third party ticket in the field, acquiesced to those terms and organized the "National Progressive Party." About a thousand delegates were present.
abstract: Progressive Repubs in Michigan hold conv, Jackson

headline: Article 1 -- No Title
abstract: elect delegates to natl conv

headline: IOWA REPUBLICANS WORRIED.; Both Factions Threaten to Cut the Ticket -- Progressives Meet.
leadPara: DES MOINES, Iowa, July 20. -- Conventions were held in many counties throughout Iowa this afternoon to name delegates to the Progressive State Convention which will be held in Des Moines on Wednesday next. Polk County followers of Col. Roosevelt held their convention in this city and named thirty-six delegates and thirty-six alternates.
abstract: both factions of Iowa progressive Repubs threaten to cut ticket

headline: TENNESSEE PROGRESSIVES BUSY; Flood the Mails with Appeals to Republican Voters.
abstract: Tennessee progressives flood mails with appeals to Repub voters to back 3d party

headline: WORKS MAY SUPPORT WILSON.; Such a Vote Would Be Consistent as a Progressive, He Says.
DIXON SILENT ON ILLINOIS.; Won't Declare Attitude on Third Ticket -- Deneen Must Speak Up.
leadPara: CHICAGO, July 21. -- Senator Joseph M. Dixon's silence on the full State third party ticket question in Illinois remains unbroken. He arrived in Chicago from Jackson, Mich., to-day, and later held several conferences with Progressive leaders, but successfully evaded all interviews with those outside the party councils.
abstract: Dixon still silent on 3d party slate in Illinois

headline: FLINN GOING TO-DAY TO SEE ROOSEVELT; Colonel Rejoices, Hoping in Conference to Reconcile the Differences in Pennsylvania.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY. L.I., July 21. -- Ex-Senator William Flinn, the Roosevelt leader in Pennsylvania, will visit Sagamore Hill to-morrow and an effort will be made then to iron out the differences that have arisen between the Colonel and his advisers over the situation there. To-day Col. Roosevelt refused to forecast the outcome of the conference.
abstract: other 3d party news

headline: REPUBLICAN VOTES WILSON WILL GET; Illuminating Batch of Letters to the Candidate Given Out at Sea Girt.
leadPara: SEA GIRT, N.J. July 21. -- In a characteristic way a group of letters received by Gov. Wilson was made public this afternoon. Gov. Wilson is very sensitive about giving out the names of his correspondents, and he is also so sensitive about his own letters to his friends that he will not discuss them in any way, leaving the initiative of making the letters public entirely to the recipients.

headline: NO THIRD TICKET IN IOWA.; Progressive Chairman Doesn't See the Necessity for One.
TAFT BAIT FOR PROGRESSIVES.; Hilles Hopes to Add Three to His Campaign Committee.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Word comes to Washington that the Republican National Committee is preparing to execute a move that it expects will strengthen the hold on the Progressives of the country who refuse to follow Col. Theodore Roosevelt into a third party and who, the committee hopes, will line up behind President Taft and work for his re-election.

headline: COLONEL MAY YIELD TO FLINN'S METHOD; Probable Outcome of Yesterday's Conference Over Pennsylvania Situation.
abstract: Roosevelt meets with Flinn; expected to yield over Penna situation; Deneen comes out for Taft; Roosevelt claims he made Deneen show his hand

headline: Article 4 -- No Title
BEVERIDGE FOR GOVERNOR.; Indiana Progressives Hope to Persuade Him to Run.
leadPara: INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 22. -- Leaders of the Progressive Party in Indiana said to-day that ex-Senator Albert J. Beveridge would surely accept the nomination for Governor of this State. At the party headquarters to-day, friends of Mr. Beveridge said he would probably make an announcement before the end of the month outlining his views with regard to the third party, and indicating his disposition toward the nomination.
abstract: Ex-Sen A J Beveridge expected to accept Progressive Party nomination for Gov

headline: ` DENEEN IS FOR TAFT.; Illinois Governor Declares His Loyalty to the President.
leadPara: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 22. -- Asked to declare his preference between President Taft or Col. Theodore Roosevelt, Gov. Deneen came out openly to-day in favor of the President. His stand was made known in a reply to the committee of five Progressive Republicans appointed recently by Medill McCormick to wait on the Governor and ascertain whom he would support for the presidency.
abstract: comment on Deneen declaration for Taft

headline: KANSAS ELECTORAL DECISION.; Both Roosevelt and Taft Men on Primary Ticket, Court Decides.
abstract: other campaign developments

headline: BULL MOOSE MEN UNITE IN JERSEY; Republicans Opposed to Taft Form Progressive Party to Support the Colonel.
leadPara: ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 23. -- New Jersey Republicans who are opposed to President Taft renounced their party today at the Beach Auditorium here and created the Progressive Party for the State, pledged to support Col. Roosevelt and his ticket. Some 1,500 delegates and spectators, the latter including many women, crowded the assembly hall.

headline: NEW JERSEY'S GOVERNOR AS THE NATION'S LEADER; Woodrow Wilson's New Title Vindicated by His Record as "Boss in the Public Interest."
abstract: eds

headline: THIRD TICKET IN VERMONT.; Progressives Nominate the Rev. Mr. Metzar for Governor.
abstract: Progressive Party conv, Burlington, adopts ticket and platform; nominates Rev F Metzar for Gov

headline: FIRST GUN IN NASSAU COUNTY.; Oft-Defeated Democrat to Preside at Opening Roosevelt Meeting.
WADSWORTH WOULD RUN FOR GOVERNOR; Ex-Speaker Announces Candidacy and Appeals to Republicans from Geneseo Home.
leadPara: GENESEO, N.Y., July 23. -- Denouncing the present State administration as "vacillating and weak" and declaring that it has accomplished "nothing for the permanent good," James W. Wadsworth, Jr., former Speaker of the Assembly, formally announced to-day his candidacy for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination.
abstract: Wadsworth formally announces candidacy, s, Geneseo

headline: HOTELS WAIT BULL MOOSE CALL; Few Rooms Reserved Yet -- Plan to Block Third Illinois Ticket.
leadPara: CHICAGO, July 23. -- There is no spontaneous outburst of applause on the part of the bonifaces of Chicago when the Bull Moose Convention, called for Aug. 5, is mentioned in their presence. In fact, there is an elongated yawn, for the hotel men of the metropolis of the Middle West see but lean pickings in the forthcoming gathering of the adherents of Col. Theodore Roosevelt.
abstract: Bird resigns to work for T Roosevelt election

headline: OSBORN WON'T AID ROOSEVELT.; Thinks Most Republicans Will Remain Regular -- Commends Wilson.
leadPara: LANSING, Mich., July 23. -- Gov. Osborn, after returning from the Upper Peninsula to-day and learning that some of the progressive party leaders still desire that he head the State ticket, although the Progressive State Convention failed to re recommend him when it met last Saturday, issued another statement praising Woodrow Wilson, and reiterating that he saw no use for a third party.

headline: PROGRESSIVES IN A WRANGLE.; Rival Factions at Nevada Convention -- Telegram from Roosevelt.
COLONEL TALKS TO COUNTY CHAIRMEN; Bull Moose "Get Together" Gathering Held at Roosevelt Headquarters Here.
leadPara: There was a round-up of the newly appointed Provisional County Chairmen of Col. Roosevelt's National Progressive Party at the State headquarters of that organization, in the Metropolitan Tower, yesterday. From all appearances, the meeting was held chiefly to let the Colonel meet his leaders and give those who are beginners in politics a chance to look the Colonel over.

headline: STATE LIFE INSURANCE.
leadPara: Wisconsin, which boasts itself the experiment station of the Progressives, offers its citizens another novelty. Having legislated in such an efficient manner that it expelled twenty-four insurance companies, the State itself now proposes to sell insurance. It does not expect to supply a cheaper article, but thinks that Government insurance will attract custom through its superiority.

headline: DEMOCRATS LIKELY TO WIN THE SENATE; Will Be Swept In on the Wilson Presidential Wave, Many Republicans Now Concede.
abstract: Other 3d party news, Bklyn, Nebraska and Nevada

headline: JUST 12 FOR BULL MOOSE.; Saratoga County Voters Few, but They Organize All the Same.
BRYAN, HEAD HUNTER OF THE BULL MOOSE; His Campaign Job Will Be to Follow the Colonel's Trail Into Every Debatable State.
leadPara: SEA GIRT, N.J., July 24. -- The question as to what is to become of William Jennings Bryan in the Democratic National campaign was seemingly answered here to-day when close political advisers of Gov. Wilson let it be known that Col. Bryan's assignment would be to worry and harass the Bull Moose candidate and to follow him into every debatable state.

headline: MUSSELMAN OUT FOR TAFT.; Michigan Gubernatorial Aspirant Won't Join the Bull Moose.
abstract: A Musselman, Grand Rapids, comes out for Roosevelt

headline: PENNSYLVANIA VIEW OF FLINN AND HIS METHODS; A Boss of Roosevelt's Own Type and a Political Opportunist Who Has Made Millions in Contracts.
leadPara: PITTSBURGH, July 23. -- William Flinn has returned to his happy home in Pittsburgh from Oyster Bay, looking just the same, and has been working off some of his Progressive enthusiasm on the golf course to-day. He is not especially communicative, but he has friends here who delight to talk about him and his methods and achievements.
abstract: Editorial on Roosevelt s (Jl 24) on 3d party aims

headline: IOWA NAMES ITS DELEGATES.; First State Convention of New Party Prepares for Chicago Gathering.
leadPara: DES MOINES, Iowa, July 24. -- The National Progressive Party held its first State convention here to-day, with 735 delegates present. The twenty-six delegates, headed by Judge John L. Stevens of Boone, named to attend the Chicago convention were instructed to vote for Theodore Roosevelt for President, whom the platform declared the "foremost citizen of the world."
abstract: Natl Progressive Party conv, Des Moines; adopts State platform

headline: Article 8 -- No Title
Opportunities for Social and Socialistic Intercourse Are Suggested.
leadPara: I would suggest that "Hopeful" visit the meetings held by reformers of various sorts, propagandists who are as eager to meet and convert her as she is herself to make friends. The city is full of these exponents of causes that are not yet popular. If she is at all progressive, she can interest herself in meetings of Socialists, single taxers, anarchists, woman suffragists, and the like.

headline: ROOSEVELT CONVENTIONS.; Delegates to Chicago Chosen in Oklahoma and Alabama.
BEVERIDGE BOLTS PARTY.; Former Senator Allies Himself with Progressives in Indiana.
abstract: Sen A J Beveridge bolts Repub Party to join Progressive Party

headline: BULL MOOSE TICKET RIGHTS.; Attorney General Carmody Thinks They Can Name Electors by Petition.
abstract: other developments

headline: BRYAN ATTACKS ROOSEVELT.; Describes Him as a Reactionary Not Worthy of Support.
abstract: Bryan ed in The Commoner terms Roosevelt a reactionary

headline: CHOOSE MARYLAND DELEGATES.; Third Party Men Rule Convention and Denounce National Committee.
abstract: Maryland Progressive Repubs conv, Baltimore, names delegates to natl Progressive conv

headline: WON'T BE ROOSEVELT DELEGATE; Racine Man Declares He Was Named Without His Consent.
LA FOLLETTE WOOL BILL PASSES SENATE; Ten Insurgents Join Democrats to Overturn Regulars, Flushed with Victory.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Extraordinary parliamentary tactics in the Senate to-day resulted at 11:15 o'clock to-night in the passage of the La Follette Wool bill that passed the Senate last Summer. Mr. La Follette's success was achieved with the aid of ten insurgent Republicans and the solid Democratic vote, the vote being 47 to 20.
abstract: Sen passes La Follette tariff bill; details

headline: BEVERIDGE TO PRESIDE.; Former Senator Chosen Temporary Chairman of Chicago Convention.
leadPara: CHICAGO, July 25. -- Announcement of the selection of Albert J. Beveridge, former United States Senator from Indiana, as Temporary Chairman of the National Progressive Convention to be held in Chicago on Aug. 5, was made to-day by United States Senator Joseph M. Dixon of Montana, director of Col. Roosevelt's campaign.
abstract: Beveridge named temporary chmn of Natl Progressive conv

headline: DEMOCRAT PRAISES COLONEL.; He Has Shown Up Corporation Corruption, Says D.A. Ball of Missouri.
REFERENDUM FOR PLATFORM.; Iowa Democrats to Submit Their Party Promises to the Electors.
leadPara: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, July 25 -- Iowa Democrats put the principles of the initiative and referendum into practice to-night by deciding at the State Convention to refer the progressive platform adopted to the vote of the rank and file of the party.
abstract: Dem Party to submit their progressive platform to voters

headline: DEMOCRATS MEET IN SYRACUSE OCT.1; State Committee Picks That City After Murphy Lets It Be Known He Favors It.
leadPara: The Democratic State Committee met at the Hotel Knickerbocker yesterday and issued a call for the Democratic State Convention to meet at Syracuse on Oct. 1. Saratoga and Rochester put in bids for the gathering, too, but Syracuse won easily after Tammany Leader Murphy had passed around word that he was in favor of holding the convention there.
abstract: NYS sets conv date

headline: ROOSEVELT AGREES TO A COMPROMISE; To Indorse Republican State Tickets in West as Trade for Electoral Support.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, N.Y., July 25. -- After a conference with Lieut. Gov. Gordon of Minnesota to-day Col. Roosevelt let it be known that in Minnesota, as well as in several other States where the Republican Party is controlled by the Progressives, he will sanction an arrangement for the indorsement of the Republican candidates on the State tickets, if they in turn will work for the Electors on the third party ticket.
abstract: Roosevelt agrees to compromise endorsements in Minnesota and other states where progressives control Repub Party

headline: THAW SENT BACK TO MATTEAWAN; " Still Insane," Court Says, and "His Discharge Would Be Dangerous to Public Peace."
abstract: Appellate Div upholds $2.5 million valuation put on Sheepshead Bay (Bklyn) race track by Tax Dept

keywords.name: organizations

headline: NAME BULL MOOSE DELEGATES.; 300 Men and Women Attend White Plains District Convention.

headline: THIRD TICKET IN PENNSYLVANIA; Colonel Has His Way in That State and Also in Colorado.
leadPara: CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- That a straight third party fight is to be made in Pennsylvania was announced by Col. Roosevelt late to-night after a long conference with ex-Senator Flinn and a committee of five delegates. It has been decided, he said, to follow the same course in Colorado.

headline: WON'T FORCE NEGRO PARTY ON SOUTH; That, Explains the Colonel to Cheering Convention, Is Why He Opposed Seating Contestants.

Col. Roosevelt was compelled to-day to take personal charge of the difficult situation growing out of the drawing of the color line.

headline: NEGRO QUESTION UP AGAIN.; Plank Embodying Jane Addams's Views Before Platform Committee.

headline: RHODE ISLAND MAY LINE UP FOR WILSON; Third Party Likely to Split Republican Vote in High-Tariff Stronghold.
leadPara: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 9. -- The political situation in Rhode Island was never in such a chaotic condition as at the present time. Neither of the two great parties, Republican and Democratic, has held its convention nor made any announcement as to a probable ticket, and the new third party, the Progressive, is to a considerable extent an unknown quantity.

headline: WILL THEY MAKE THE SACRIFICE?
leadPara: Mr. ROOSEVELT will open his campaign in Providence, R.I., next week. Will his candidacy, his oratory, and his Socialistic principles sweep the Republicans of that State into the third-term fold? Will they trust themselves to the precarious footing of his platform, and follow him in his exceedingly doubtful venture, at the risk of losing control of their State and the possession of its offices?

leadPara: OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 12. -- Senator Dixon, Chairman of the National Committee, and George W. Perkins, Chairman of the Executive Committee are expected at Sagamore Hill to-morrow to discuss and attempt to solve the many problems which are facing the new Progressive Party.

headline: FLINN ULTIMATUM ANGERS TAFT MEN; Pennsylvania Congressmen Are Roused to Fighting Mood by Bull Mooser's Terms
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- The threatened ultimatum from William Flinn of Pittsburgh, the Bull Moose leader of Pennsylvania, was received to-day by Republican Congressmen from that State, and caused a great stir. headline: CANAL BILL VOTE MAY END TREATIES; Feared Britain Won't Renew Hay-Pauncefote Convention, Which Expires Next April.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- Prominent Senators this afternoon were seriously alarmed to discover that our twenty-five arbitration treaties with nearly every civilized country in the world are seriously imperiled by our course on the Panama Canal bill. To their surprise they discovered this afternoon that our arbitration treaty with Great Britain, which figured so prominently in the Senate debates on the no-toll question, will expire by limitation next April.

headline: SENATE ANTI-ROOSEVELT.; Vote Shows Six Insurgents Against Third Term Boom.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- In an unexpected way the Senate was forced to record its position to-day for or against the third-term candidacy of Col. Roosevelt. Though the vote cannot be taken as absolute, as it was complicated by other considerations, it did not show the Colonel's support as very strong in the Senate.

headline: PROGRESSIVES OF THE STAGE; What the Playwright Stands for in the Modern Theatre -- Meeting the Demands of an Enlightened Public.

headline: Roosevelt's Claims Are Shaky.
leadPara: TRACY CITY, Tenn., Aug. 17. -- Roosevelt's claim of a large Democratic vote in the South is not well founded. Wilson's nomination gives such general satisfaction that he will poll the full Democratic vote.

headline: SINCERISTS' SOCIETY TO SOLVE OUR ILLS; Founder C.E. Ellis Would Write Across the Sky the Great Cause of Trouble.
leadPara: A new organization, to be known as the Society of Sincerists, has been born. It sprang from the mind of Charles Edwin Ellis, who several months ago resigned his place as Secretary, Treasurer, and Director of the American Finance and Securities Company, 5 Nassau Street. He has severed his connections with two other concerns in order to devote his entire time to the cause of sincerity.

headline: WILSON SPENT SUNDAY HERE.; While He Was Gone the Crowds Took All His Apples.
leadPara: SEA GIRT, Aug. 18. -- Around and around the Little White House an expectant throng circled to-day in the hope that it could catch a glimpse and then a handshake of the Democratic Presidential candidate. But the candidate had fled as usual for Sunday and surrendered his rocking chairs, verandas, lawns, shrubbery, and all to the multitude.

leadPara: DOVER, Del., Aug. 18. -- The primaries held throughout Delaware yesterday for the election of delegates to the Republican State Convention here Tuesday were not decisive. headline: ROOSEVELT SUPPORT WEAKER; Taft Grows Stronger In Washington State -- Colonel's Visit Too Early.
leadPara: TACOMA, Wash., Aug. 18. -- Washington Republicans have awakened to the fact that organization and work are necessary to carry the State for Taft and elect two or more Republican Congressmen. As a new State Committee cannot be chosen and organized under the primary law until the last week in September, work will be started by the present State Committee, which meets here Thursday.

headline: MOOSE DISCORDS IN JERSEY.; The Fort-Record-Colby Quarrel Is Not Helping Third Party Here.

Whiting, ex-Senator Colby's law partner, has not brought harmony to the ranks of the Progressives of New Jersey, and both Colby and his old ally. George L. Record, have since been filling the local newspapers with epistolary attacks on each other.

headline: ASK BANKS TO ACCEPT CASH FOR CAMPAIGN; Wilson's Managers Would Have Them Receive Funds for All Parties.

headline: MR. ROOSEVELT IN THE SOUTH.

headline: TAFT SEEKS TO SOLVE FREE CANAL ISSUE; Is for Toll Exemption to Our Ships, but Appreciates British Objections.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- The President has still not made up his mind whether to sign the Panama Canal bill or to veto it and return it to Congress for amendment. But he made it plain to his callers to-day that he now has at least two important objections to the measure as it stands.

headline: No Chance in North Carolina.
leadPara: ASHEVILLE, N.C., Aug. 17. -- Col. Roosevelt can have no reasonable hope of carrying North Carolina or any Southern State. In the support of Gov. Wilson the Democratic Party of this State and of the whole South is united, determined and enthusiastic. Factions have disappeared.

headline: STANDARD OIL CHECK USED FOR ROOSEVELT; Penrose Lets It Be Known That Money He Obtained from Archbold Went Into Campaign.

headline: TAFT NOT TO PICK NEW YORK CANDIDATE; Repeats That He Will Not Take Sides as to a Nominee for Governor.

Stimson, Secretary of War, would be the strongest man for the Republicans to put up for Governor of New York was the opinion voiced to-night by Fred Greiner, Postmaster at Buffalo, who arrived in town five hours too late to keep a luncheon engagement with President Taft at Parramatta this afternoon.
abstract: Taft will remain neutral in choice of Repub candidate; Postmaster F Greiner favors Stimson

headline: AEROPLANES MAKE WAR GAME USELESS; British Manoeuvres Are Abandoned as a Result of the Effective Air Scouting.
leadPara: CAMBRIDGE, England, Sept. 18. -- Aviation, apparently, will revolutionize warfare. An official announcement was issued to-night that the army manoeuvres had been abandoned and that a military conference would be held here to-morrow morning to adjudge the results and explain the cessation of operations.

headline: WILL OUST HORSE BY COMPETITION; Power Wagon Will Come Into Its Own by Sane and Conservative Methods.
leadPara: The value of the power wagon for facilitating transportation by road is becoming more apparent daily, and that it has achieved a success is because it is superior to the horse-drawn vehicle even under methods pertaining to horse transportation in the great majority of cases. It will, however, show its true worth only when horse traditions are a memory of the past.

headline: PUTS LAY TESTIMONY ABOVE THE DOCTORS'; Surrogate Fowler Overrules the Insanity "Experts" in Upholding O.E. Schmidt's Will.
leadPara: In spite of the testimony of half a dozen doctors that Oscar Egerton Schmidt, once treasurer of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, and later general manager of the Lawyers Mortgage and Trust Company, suffered from a progressive form of insanity and was incompetent before he drew a contested codicil to his will, Surrogate Fowler has decided to admit the codicil to probate. He will announce his decision to-morrow.

headline: ROOSEVELT PARTY FIND WILSON IN LEAD; Only California Conceded to Colonel and Utah to Taft Throughout the Entire West.
leadPara: ON BOARD THE ROOSEVELT TRAIN, Kansas City, Mo., Sept. 22. -- Col. Roosevelt allowed himself a day of rest today, and spent most of it in Emporia, Kan., in the restful company of William Allen White. He went to the Dutch Reformed Church in the morning and visited the White newspaper plant. Otherwise the day was not exciting.

headline: STRAUS MAKES CONDITIONS.; Any Party Nominating Him Must Accept the Rochester Platform.
leadPara: Oscar S. Straus, the Progressive nominee for Governor, while denying that he had sent a message to Frederick K. Roosevelt, got back yesterday from his 11,000-mile campaign tour, apparently little the worse for wear, and all ready, he said, to start in again after a few hours' rest. His train arrived at the Pennsylvania Station, New York, at 4 o'clock, and the Colonel found an enthusastic little band of Progressive leaders awaiting him.

Murphy refused to indicate his choice for Governor until the delegates had clearly indicated their own Representative William Sulzer was nominated for Governor by the Democratic State Convention shortly after 1 o'clock this morning.

Henry Clay Sulzer."

headline: IN TIGER'S CLUTCH, SAYS STRAUS; Thinks Sulzer the Best Man Tammany Could Select for Governor.
leadPara: UTICA, Oct. 3. -- Oscar S. Straus, Bull Moose candidate for Governor, when asked to-day for his view of Mr. Sulzer's nomination as his Democratic opponent, said the Congressman was probably the best man Tammany could select, but that he was "in the clutch of the Tiger."

headline: DIX PRAISES HIS RECORD.; Says Convention's Approval Justified His Seeking a Renomination.

Dix commented on the action of the Democratic State Convention to-day in a statement which declared that the convention's indorsement of his administration justified his "attitude toward a renomination." The Governor also stated that he had received many telegrams expressing regret at the failure of the party to renominate him.

headline: REPUBLICAN PLANS WORRY ROOSEVELT; Colonel Doesn't Like the Idea of Special Train with Taft Speakers Hot on His Trail.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, N.Y., Oct. 6. -- Col. Roosevelt had a last talk with his leaders at Sagamore Hill to-day before starting on his second tour of the Middle West. He had been told by his managers that to hope for victory he must fight on to the finish, and the Colonel is ready for a whirlwind finish.

headline: PROGRESSIVES RUN THIRD.; Beaten in Stamford -- Connecticut Democrats Get Four Mayors.
leadPara: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 7. -- To-day was was "Town Meeting Day" for the small towns of Connecticut, and the chief interest centred in the license vote. This year fifty-four towns voted on the question, forty of them voting for license. There are now eighty-one license towns in the State, and eighty-seven no-license, as compared with seventy-five license and ninety-three no-license towns last year.

headline: M'KINLEY RAISED $265,000 FOR TAFT; Placidly Forgetful, He Admits the President's Brothers Gave $150,000 of It.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- That the Taft headquarters in Washington raised $265,000 to finance the contest for the renomination of the President was the testimony given by Representative William B. Stotesbury, and John Hays Hammond gave $25,000 each.

headline: Article 1 -- No Title
leadPara: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 20. -- A search of the records of the last California Legislature shows that Gov. Johnson is perfectly safe in remaining away from California beyond the sixty days provided in the statutes. It seems that a resolution was passed giving the members leave to absent themselves from the State longer than sixty days, and it include Gov. Johnson.
abstract: details

headline: Article 6 -- No Title
leadPara: LITTLE FALLS, N.Y., Oct 20. -- The Herkimer County authorities declared tonight that while they had given permission to the Socialist Party of the State to hold a public meeting to-morrow at noon in the public park, which is directly in front of several knitting mills whose employes are on strike, their attitude in regard to future meetings was undecided.
abstract: sends message to Herkimer County authorities and Socialists at Little Falls, reminding them of free speech guarantee under NYS Const; Socialists plan pub meeting at which Lunn and C E Russell will s

headline: JOHNSON WILL MAKE FIGHT IN THE EAST; Hurries to New York for Whirlwind Tour Along Lines Col. Roosevelt Had Planned.
leadPara: CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- Gov. Hiram W. Johnson is to take Col. Roosevelt's place in the final Progressive campaign in the East. He will not lose the Governorship of California, either, although he will be absent from that State more than sixty days and there is a statute forbidding such absence, on pain of losing office.
abstract: issues pub statement to people of Calif asking their indulgence

headline: CHURCHILL DEMANDS SERVICE OF CHURCH; Progressive Candidate Declares Religion Should Enter Strongly Into Politics.
leadPara: The Diocesan Social Service Commission held a social welfare meeting yesterday afternoon in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, at which the need for church social service was summed up by the Right Rev. John N. McCormick, Bishop of Western Michigan, the principal speaker, who said the Church must not only seek to play the good Samaratin, but must clean up the Jericho road.

headline: SIXTH COLUMN FOR MOOSE.; Attorney General Carmody Upholds Lazansky's Decision.
WILSON TO ADDRESS REPUBLICAN LEAGUE; At Rally in Philadelphia of Progressive Republicans Who Are Supporting a Democrat.
leadPara: Unless Col. Roosevelt suffers a relapse, Gov. Wilson will be the chief speaker and central figure at an independent Republican mass meeting in Philadelphia on Monday, Oct. 28. The meeting will be under the auspices of the Wilson National Progressive Republican League, of which Rudolph Spreckels is President, and will be in charge of the Pennsylvania branch of the league.

headline: ROOSEVELT HOLDS STRENGTH ON TRIP; Due Here This Morning and Will Be Rushed to Oyster Bay for Rest.
leadPara: ON BOARD THE ROOSEVELT TRAIN. PITTSBURGH, Penn., Oct. 21. -- Col. Roosevelt showed no ill-effects to-night from his all-day ride from Chicago on his way home to recover from the bullet wound in his chest. He is expected to reach Oyster Bay to-morrow morning in as good condition as he left Mercy Hospital this morning.
abstract: Roosevelt on way to Sagamore Hill by train; crowds along train route pay silent tribute

headline: HASBROUCK ON THE BALLOT.; Appellate Division Sustains His Claim, Two Justices Dissenting.
leadPara: ALBANY, Oct. 21. -- The Appellate Division, Third Department, to-night affirmed the decision of Supreme Court Justice Chester to the effect that G.D.B. Hasbrouck of Kingston was entitled to a place on the official ballot as the Progressive Party's candidate for Supreme Court Justice in the Third Judicial District.

headline: STRAUS IS CONFIDENT OF VICTORY HERE; Sure That Roosevelt and Progressive State Ticket Will Carry New York.
leadPara: CHICAGO, Oct. 21. -- Oscar S. Straus, Progressive candidate for Governor of New York, was the recipient of a remarkable ovation in the chief city of Illinois to-day. At the Garrick Theatre, in the centre of the great "loop" district, thousands who desired to hear Mr. Straus discuss the issues of the campaign were turned away.

headline: HEDGES ON POLICE EVILS.; Says as Governor He'd Oust Commissioner if Life Here Was Menaced.
leadPara: MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- Job E. Hedges, Republican candidate for Governor, addressing a large and friendly audience at the theatre here to-day, attacked Tammany Hall and the Progressive Party. The Progressives could not win, he said, but if they united with the Democrats they might be able to elect a Democratic Legislature which would be controlled by Tammany.

headline: PLANNED EARLY TO NAME COLONEL; W.L. Ward Approached Penrose Two Weeks Before Governors Met, Philadelphians Assert.
abstract: Perkins denies Repub leaders charges concerning financing of Bull Moose campaign, Sen com hearing; Nugent gives evidence to show work was being done in Phila last Dec in behalf of Roosevelt nomination

headline: JOHNSON BEGINS TOUR FOR COLONEL; Aided by Cockran, Clapp, and Beveridge, He Will Fill Roosevelt's Eastern Engagements.
leadPara: Gov. Hiram W. Johnson of California, the Bull Moose candidate for Vice President, who came to New York yesterday in order to fill so far as he could the Eastern speaking engagements of Col. Roosevelt, conferred with the Bull Moose leaders here and then departed for Camden, N.J. From now until Oct. 30 Gov. Johnson will tour the States which Col. Roosevelt had planned to visit before he was shot.
abstract: Johnson doubts he will be deposed as Gov for staying outside State beyond time allowed by law, s, NYC

headline: MRS. JOHNSON'S GEMS ASTRAY IN WALDORF; Diamond Bird She Wore Lay on an Elevator Floor for Hours Unseen.
leadPara: Whoever spread the report that Mrs. Hiram Johnson, wife of the Vice Presidential nominee on the Progressive ticket, had lost a Bull Moose emblem in the Waldorf the other day, it turned out yesterday, was mistaken. What Mrs. Johnson lost was a duck, and one peculiarity about the incident was that the duck stayed lost in the hotel for almost three hours.

headline: BIG SILENT VOTE IN ORANGE COUNTY; While Republican Poll Shows Taft Majority, Many Refuse to Commit Themselves.
leadPara: NEWBURG, Oct. 21. -- On the strength of a secret poll which has just been completed the Republican campaign managers here declare to-night that Orange County, which two years ago came within an ace of going Democratic, will roll up a comfortable majority for President Taft this year.
abstract: Campaign developments

headline: The Times's Campaign News.
ENTITLED TO REGISTRATION.; Disqualified Bronx Voters Could Have Secured a Mandamus.
leadPara: Referring to to-day's letter, in which Mr. Abraham Lipsky states that the Registration Board which sat at 1,102 Garrison Avenue, in the Bronx, being the Thirty-third Election District of the Thirty-second Assembly District, closed down sharply at 10, with some-fifty or sixty men in line, I would state that the law provides that the inspectors should not refuse to register those who are present within the place of registration at the time of closing.

headline: VOTES AT 94; A MOOSETTE.; Aged California Woman Will Cast Her First Ballot for Roosevelt.
PERKINS A PLUGGED NICKEL.; That's What Hearing of Ryan's $450,000 Made Him Feel Like.
leadPara: George W. Perkins. Chairman of the Executive Committee of the National Progressive Party, returned from Washington yesterday, where he testified before the Clapp Committee investigating campaign contributions and immediately got down again to the work of running the Bull Moose campaign.
abstract: Perkins comments on Ryan contribution of $450,000, int, NYC

headline: CLAPP COMMITTEE CALLS BEVERIDGE; Two Democrats, with Oliver, Overrule Clapp on Summoning Indiana Progressive
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- After two lively sessions held behind closed doors, to determine its future action, the Clapp committee by a vote of three to one decided to-day to summon ex-Senator A.J. Beveridge of Indiana, now Progressive candidate for Governor, to appear at the public session to-morrow, which is expected to be the last before election.
abstract: Westchester County Repub leader W L Ward says campaign for Roosevelt nomination was started early last fall

headline: LA FOLLETTE AND ROOSEVELT; Amos Pinchot Replies to the Senator's Charge of Treachery.
abstract: A Pinchot defends his, his bro's and others loyalty to La Follette, lr

headline: THIRD PARTY RUNS THIRD IN ULSTER; Forecast of Vote in County Shows Battle to be Between the Old Parties.
leadPara: KINGSTON, Oct. 22. -- With three parties in the field, Ulster County, which four years ago gave "William H. Taft a majority of 1,975 votes, will be in the doubtful column this year, with the probabilities favoring a Democratic victory. The fight is between the two old parties, and, unless conditions change very radically in the next two weeks, it is safe to predict that the Bull Moose ticket will run a bad third.
abstract: forecast of vote in Ulster County indicates Dem victory

headline: ROOSEVELT AT HOME, LETS THE DOCTORS GO; Assures Them He's "All Right" When They Are Reluctant to Leave Him for a Day.
abstract: Roosevelt arrives home; sends drs away

headline: TOPICS OF THE TIMES.
leadPara: It was entirely commendable, of course, tat the Mayor, as Mrs. AMOS PINCHOT admitted, expressed with courtesy his refusal to let the women of the National Progressive Party in this city raise money for it by means of what has become much too familiar as a "tag day."
abstract: ed comment lauding Gaynor for banning Natl Progressive Party women from holding tag day

headline: MOOSETTES TAKE TO PARKS.; With Gaynor's Veto on Tag Day, They Plan Open-Air Meetings.
leadPara: Not to be daunted by Mayor Gaynor's decision not to allow the women sympathizers of the Bull Moose movement to hold a "tag day" next Saturday and solicit contributions for the Progressive cause, the women members of the new party intend to accomplish what they originally set out to do by holding a number of public meeting in twelve of the city's park.
abstract: Women to hold open-air meetings, NYC, instead of tag day

headline: PRAISE FROM SIR HUBERTS.
leadPara: The foreign delegates to the International Congress of Chambers of Commerce were of course of exceptional intelligence and authority in all matters pertaining to trade and industry. For that reason it is important to take note that their observations of such matters in the United States differ from much that is published here.

headline: MILWAUKEE CHEERS STRAUS.; He Says La Follette's Pride Keeps Him Away from Moosers.
abstract: Straus s for Wilson in Milwaukee

headline: BEVERIDGE REFUSED $57,000 FUND IN 1904; Witnesses Say Gifts Returned Included Three $10,000 Drafts from G.W. Perkins.
abstract: Whitman opens probe; details

headline: TAFT HOLDS ALBANY, CHANCE FOR STRAUS; Anti-Boss Sentiment Will Throw Many Gubernatorial Votes to the Third Party.
leadPara: ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 23. -- The political bailiwick of William Barnes, Jr., will follow in the footsteps of its overlord and "stand pat." Albany County, according to all present indications, will return a plurality for William H. Taft and the Republican State ticket. All around it, however, is territory until recently safely Republican, where the Bull Moose has made such heavy inroads that a Republican victory this year is out of the question.

headline: CINCINNATI CHEERS STRAUS.; His References to Woman Suffrage Elicit Special Applause.
leadPara: CINCINNATI, Oct. 23. -- When Oscar Straus, Progressive candidate for Governor of New York State, mounted the speakers' platform in Music Hall to-night he was received with a tempest of applause. Mr. Straus set about to win his audience, and he did so with great success, with his humorous references to his own candidacy for the governorship.

headline: SHERMAN, 57 TO-DAY, SAYS WE FACE CRISIS; Issues Statement to the People, Ill-Health Preventing Him Joining in Campaign.
leadPara: UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 23. -- Vice President James S. Sherman will spend his fifty-seventh birthday to-morrow quietly at his home here, and receive only members of his family and a few intimate friends. Mr. Sherman has been improving in health more rapidly the past two weeks than at any time since his serious illness early in the Summer.

headline: ROOSEVELT ADMITS ONLY ONE DOCTOR; And He Knows the Patient Wants No Talk About Condition -- Says He'll Make That Speech.
abstract: Roosevelt allows 1 dr to attend him; med bulletin issued; he insists on speaking at Madison Sq Garden Oct 30th as planned

headline: CANDIDATES SPENT LITTLE.; Congressional Expense Accounts Thus Far Filed Are Modest.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- Very few candidates for Congress have made returns to the Clerk of the House of Representatives in compliance with the Federal act requiring candidates to file a preliminary statement of their election expenses not more than fifteen and not less than ten days before the election.
abstract: HR campaign expense accts thus far filed are modest; some NYS candidates expenditures listed

headline: McCOMBS SURE OF WEST.; Wilson Campaign Will Cost $1,000,000 -- $550,000 Spent.
leadPara: William F. McCombs, Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, returned from Chicago yesterday with glowing reports of conditions in the Middle Western States. Illinois, he said, was safe for Wilson.
abstract: McCombs claims Midwest is for Wilson; estimates Wilson campaign will cost $1 million; repts $550,000 spent to date; Albany County reptd for Taft; Straus s in Cincinnati; Wilson gives ser in 1st Presb Ch, Trenton; Sherman issues statement on maj issues of campaign; other campaign developments

headline: STRAUS ENDS HIS TOUR.; Speaks to 4,500 Enthusiastic Hearers in Cleveland -- Starts for Home.
leadPara: CLEVELAND, Oct. 24. -- Oscar S. Straus, Secretary of Commerce and Labor in President Roosevelt's Cabinet, and Bull Moose candidate for Governor of New York, speaking to-night at the Central Armory as "a humble messenger of the Progressive movement," brought to Cleveland Bull Moosers the message that "Progressivism is marching on, and as it marches forward is sweeping the bosses out and bringing back the rule of the people."
abstract: Straus ends his pro-Progressive Party speaking tour at Cleveland

headline: SULZER SPEAKS AT ALBANY.; He Laughs at the Criticism of Bosses by the Barnes-Ridden Republicans.
leadPara: ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- William Sulzer made a whirlwind tour of Albany County's three cities this afternoon and evening. He and Martin H. Glynn, the candidate for Lieutenant Governor, motored from Schenectady to Cohoes after dinner in a heavy rain.
abstract: Sulzer and Glynn s in Albany; Sulzer again says he is unbossed; Hedges sends wire to Sulzer challenging him to give history of Miller Plantation Co of Vera Cruz and Hedges connection with it; wire text; Hedges says fight is between him and Sulzer, ss, Corning and Olean

headline: BULL MOOSE FUNDS FIGURE UP $304,116; Frank A. Munsey Gives $70,000 and Geo. W. Perkins $45,000 -- Expenses $292,756.
leadPara: The National Progressive Party received in contributions to its campaign fund from July 1 to Oct. 17, 1912, $304,116 and spent $292,756, according to a statement of its financial transactions filed yesterday with the Clerk of the House of Representatives at Washington by National Treasurer E.H. Hooker, in accordance with the recent campaign contribution law.
abstract: Natl Progressive Party repts campaign fund totals $304,116

HOTEL MEN TO FIGHT.; Will Close Restaurants Before Contracting with Waiters, They Say.
leadPara: The committee of hotel proprietors and managers in charge of the training school for waiters, butlers and others established after the last strike of hotel employes in this city after met yesterday afternoon.
abstract: over 120 regis voters involved in probe deny they voted

headline: ROOSEVELT SUING FOR CRIMINAL LIBEL; Intends to Settle, Once for All, the Charges That He Is Intemperate in Habit and Speech.
leadPara: Believing that he can end once for all the stories that come up from time to time that he is an excessive drinker of intoxicating liquors, Col. Roosevelt has brought criminal and civil actions for libel in the Circuit Court of Marquette, Mich., against George A. Newett, publisher of The Iron Ore, a weekly newspaper published at Ishpeming, Mich.
abstract: Roosevelt brings libel suits in Marquette, Mich, against Iron Ore publisher G A Newett for Oct 12th article charging Roosevelt drinks to excess, lies and curses; Newett arrested, freed on bail; his reaction to suits

headline: DR. CARREL FINDS ANOTHER WONDER; Keeps Vital Organs of One Dog Alive After Separating Them from the Body.
leadPara: The world of experimental medicine was humming yesterday with the announcement of the latest discovery of Dr. Alexis Carrel of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, an announcement made on Thursday night before an applauding and deeply interested assemblage of doctors, the members and guests of the New York Physicians' Association, who filled Tuxedo Hall to overflowing.
abstract: Carrel tells of his success in keeping vital organs of dog alive after separating them from body, s, NY Physicians Assn; details

headline: DR. ROOSEVELT EVER READY.; Has Night Bell and Both Telephones, Says Gov. Marshall.
25 ALBANY INDICTMENTS; Arise Out of Disorderly Conditions Charged -- City Officials Exonerated.
leadPara: ALBANY, Oct. 25. -- Twenty-five sealed indictments were presented to-day by the Grand Jury drawn to serve with the Extraordinary Term of the Supreme Court convened by Gov. Dix to investigate criminal conditions alleged to exist in Albany by the Senate inquiry a year ago.
abstract: grand jury indicts 25; city officials exonerated

headline: LET PEOPLE RULE, PUT THREE WAYS; Academy of Political Science Gets Primary Views from the Candidates for Governor.
leadPara: At the dinner of the Academy of Political Science of New York, at the Hotel Astor last night, written statements were read from the three Gubernatorial candidates, explaining their positions on direct primary legislation. Before the statements were presented, the topic, "The Direct Primary Versus the Convention Method of Choosing Candidates for Public Office," was discussed by Prof. Albert Bushnell Hart of Harvard and State Senator Edgar T. Brackett.
abstract: Annual dinner and meeting, NYC

headline: EVEN ST. LAWRENCE SCARES REPUBLICANS; Bull Moose Call in the Wilderness Has Forced Them to Make a Real Campaign.
leadPara: OGDENSBURG, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- For the first time in the memory of living politicians in St. Lawrence the Republicans here have been reduced to the necessity of conducting a real campaign. For the first time, also, the Republican campaign managers, ten days before election, are not able to predict to a nicety what the Republican vote will be.

headline: WILSON NOT ANXIOUS FOR EARLY RETURNS; Would Rather Retire at 9 P.M. Election Night and Wait Till Morning.
leadPara: PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 26. -- Gov. Woodrow Wilson put aside politics for two hours and a half to-day to watch the Princeton football eleven administer a drubbing to Dartmouth. For a Presidential candidate to escape the issues of the campaign any longer than that he found to be utterly impossible.
abstract: Wilson campaign developments

headline: COST OF THEIR CAMPAIGNS.; Congressmen File Returns -- Underwood Spent Nothing.
abstract: Repub Natl Com files list; several Congressmen file repts

headline: THREW A DIAMOND AWAY.; Second Finder Was Wiser and Kept It for Owner.
leadPara: At a big hotel not over half a mile from Times Square, which may be further identified by the fact that some of the employee can afford to wear diamonds, a good-sized brilliant went begging for a time Friday morning. It was lost by its owner, found, thrown away, and then found again.
abstract: Hitchings denies he is anti-semitic as charged in anon lr to NY Times

headline: ASSERTS BEVERIDGE BOASTED OF BIG FUND; Republican Leader Says He Threatened to Take Charge of Indiana Canvass in 1904.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Ex-Senator Albert J. Beveridge's return of contributions of $57,500 after the legislative campaign of 1904 -- the details of which have attracted much attention in the recent sessions of the Senate Campaign Committee inquiry -- was put in a new light today.
abstract: com hears Indiana Repub leader H C Starr on Beveridge return of contributions; Beveridge again testifies; com adjourns until after election

headline: HOW PUTNAM'S BOSS CHANGED STATE ROAD; John R. Yale Got Highway Commission to Substitute Elm Tree for De Forest Route.
HAVERFORD COLLEGE.; Dean Lewis of Pennsylvania and T.R. White Address Students.
leadPara: HAVERFORD, Penn., Oct. 26. -- Haverford has been one of the few American colleges which has made soccer football a leading sport in previous years. Recently, however, a movement was started by many of the larger colleges and universities' to popularize this game. To meet this growing competition special attention will be paid to the game this year.

headline: WITH THE VASSAR GIRLS.; Students Almost Effect a Corner in Presidential Candidates.
leadPara: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- Monday was an important day in the political campaign at Vassar. The Republican convention met in Assembly Hall at 3:45 o'clock. Delegates were there from all the States. They were elected last week at the primaries. The press was well represented by an active body of reporters, among them a suffragist.

headline: POLITICS FOR SUNDAY.
leadPara: It is appropriate to the day to remark amid the tumult and the shouting of the partisans that a very different note from theirs is struck simultaneously and harmoniously by two leaders of thought so far apart as the President of the Steel Trust and the Secretary of the Charity Organization Society.

headline: JEFFERSON LIKELY TO BE DEMOCRATIC; Republican Figures on Bull Moose Defection Indicate That Wilson and Sulzer Will Carry County.
leadPara: WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- It is a common saying here, in these closing days of the Presidential campaign, that you may scratch a Jefferson County Republican, in perfectly good standing with his organization, and find a full-fledged Progressive.
abstract: Watertown

headline: CONSERVATION OF MEN TO CROWN "NEW INDUSTRIAL DAY"; Representative W.C. Redfield of Brooklyn Writes of the Dawn of a New Era in the Business World --- Avoidance of Waste --- Improved Efficiency Methods Second to Humane Treatment of Workers and Increase of Human Comfort.
leadPara: THE Congressional Directory says that Representative William Cox Redfield of Brooklyn, Democrat, tariff reformer, once Commissioner of Public Works in Brooklyn, and recently a candidate for Vice President before the Democratic National Convention, is a manufacturer of iron and steel forgings and tools in Brooklyn, and that he also makes ventilating, heating, and drying apparatus in Detroit.

headline: OSCAR STRAUS SAYS HE HAS TWO STICKS; One Is for Barnes and the Other for Murphy, He Tells Audience in Yonkers.
leadPara: Oscar S. Straus, the Progressive candidate for Governor, swept down from Yonkers through the Bronx into Harlem last night in an automobile, speaking at five meetings. He won applause from his hearers by asserting that he carried two big sticks, one for Barnes and one for Murphy.
abstract: Beveridge and T Woodruff predict nationwide Progressive victories, ss, Bklyn

headline: FOUND SOME FUNDS ON FOUNDERS' DAY; But Treasure Ship of Progressive Women Will Not Founder from Weight of Coin.
leadPara: The women of the Finance Committee of the Progressive Party celebrated Founders' Day yesterday all over the United States. The day marks officially the birth of their party, as well as the birth of Col. Roosevelt, who is fifty-four to-day.
abstract: Founders day marked throughout US

headline: DOUBT DIX'S RIGHT TO RETIRE O'RYAN; Senate's Assent to Dismissal of a Major General Necessary, State Guardsmen Assert.
leadPara: ALBANY, Oct. 26. -- Gov. Dix's drastic order retiring Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan aroused much comment to-day. The question has arisen whether the Governor has not exceeded his authority in disbanding a division of the National Guard and re tiring Gen. O'Ryan to the supernumerary list, with the intention of re-establishing the division later.
abstract: many Guard officers question legality of Dix action without Sen approval; Verbeck reorganizes certain branches; details

headline: WHAT THE WELL-DRESSED WOMAN IS WEARING; The New Gowns on American Women--Certain French Fashions Adopted Here Without Change--Others Are Refused.
leadPara: IT IS not probable that other days in fashion created as much turmoil and argument and individual opinion as the last three years have fostered. What is the reason? Is it the duty on clothes, with the immense publicity entailed of women's purchases abroad? Is it the progressive spirit, which in America is beginning to challenge everything?

headline: FEDERAL CONTROL OF TRUSTS A STEP TOWARD DESPOTISM; R.R. Reed, Who Drafted the Williams Bill, Points Out the Menace to the Entire Social Ideal of American Democracy in the Progressive Party Plan.
leadPara: READERS of THE TIMES have had presented to them since the beginning of the campaign the views of the highest American and international authorities on the big issue of this year's contest, the control of overgrown business -- the "trusts."

headline: REPUBLICAN SMASH ABOVE THE BRONX; Democrats to Make at Strong Rural Showing and Moosers to Poll a Big Vote.
leadPara: SYRACUSE, Oct. 27. -- Old-time Republican majorities in up-State counties will go to smash in the coming election. The Democratic vote in rural sections will be of unprecedented proportions. The vote for the candidates of the National Progressive Party in certain sections will be of surprising magnitude.
abstract: Dos Passos lr to Mack opposes making list of campaign contributors pub

headline: UNTERMYER PRODS JOHNSON FOR WILSON; Asks Why He Hasn't Suppressed Trusts in California as He Would Have Wilson Do Here.
leadPara: Samuel Untermyer in a letter yesterday to Chairman William F. McCombs of the Democratic National Committee answered the attacks which the Bail Moose leaders, notably Gov. Hiram W. Johnson of California, have been making on Gov. Wilson for his alleged failure to take action for the suppression of the trusts organized under New Jersey charters.
abstract: Utermyer lr to McCombs answers Bull Moose charges against Wilson

headline: ONE BULL MOOSE COLLAPSE.; Party in Washington Demoralized -- Leader Involved in Scandal.

headline: ONE BELMONT WITH BRYAN.; Perry Speaks on the Same Platform In Chicago Meetings.
leadPara: CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- Politicians who remember how William J. Bryan at the Baltimore convention sought to read August Belmont out of the Democratic Pary, remarked to-day that the Nebraskan's feeling apparently did not extend to other members of the New York banker's family.
abstract: S, Chicago; labels self progressive Dem

headline: DEMOCRATS EXPECT BIG HOUSE MAJORITY; Republicans Concede That They Will Largely Increase Their Lead in Congressional Contests.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- There is general agreement among political observers of all parties that in the House of Representatives of the Sixty-third Congress, nearly all the members of which will be elected on Nov. 5, the Democrats will have an overwhelming majority. Even Republicans of the most intense partisan type admit this.
abstract: Repubs concede Dems will elect overwhelming majority to 63d Cong

headline: WHAT CANDIDATES SPENT.; Nearly 1,000 Make Returns -- Hicks and Cannon File Biggest Statements.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The office of the Clerk of the House was swamped to-day by the arrival of preliminary statements of campaign expenditures from nearly a thousand candidates all over the country. Many say that their campaigns cost them nothing, while others file statements of heavy expenditures.

headline: TAFT MEN WORKING TO SAVE ONONDAGA; " Prosperity Special" of Automobiles Out to Stem the Tide of Progressives' Enthusiasm.
leadPara: SYRACUSE, Oct. 28. -- In Onondaga, home of rock-ribbed Republicanism, history has kept on repeating itself every four years with a regularity very pleasing to the party in power. This year may prove an exception. In the past a Presidential campaign has been little more than a frolic to the Onondaga Republicans.
abstract: Dem State Com sure of Sulzer victory

headline: SUFFRAGE CHARIOT FOR COL. ROOSEVELT; Chief Mooser Invited to Ride in a Golden Vehicle in November Parade.
leadPara: Theodore Roosevelt may ride in a golden chariot in the big suffrage torchlight procession on Saturday evening, Nov. 9.
abstract: Roosevelt int on his condition and speaking plans

headline: WOMEN RUN AUTO COAST TO COAST; Miss Copley and Mrs. Raum of San Diego, California, Make Trip for Vacation.
leadPara: Somebody has crossed the continent in an automobile, once in a while, lately, but usually the journey has been undertaken to advertise a car, or a tire, or something else appertaining to manufacturers' publicity. At the Plaza are two women who the other day completed an auto trip from San Diego, Cal., to Boston, and it was undertaken, so they said yesterday, just to pass a pleasant Summer vacation.
abstract: find 42 saloons open on Sunday

headline: AFTER ALL, COLONEL ADDS TO SPEECHES; After Madison Square Garden He'll Talk Near Home, but This He Doesn't Count.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- "How does it feel?" asked one of the Old Guard, trying to get at exactly what might be the Colonel's sensations with a bullet in him.

headline: GOOD MEETING FOR STRAUS.; Never Before Such a Crowd Out at Glen Cove as One to Hear Him.
leadPara: GLEN COVE, L.I., Oct. 28. -- The little opera house in this village was crowded to-night as it never was before, and there were almost as many persons on the outside unable to get in when Oscar S. Straus, the Progressive candidate for Governor, spoke. Mr. Straus got a fine reception.
abstract: Straus and Davenport s in Glen Cove, LI

headline: THIEVES BIND GIRL, ROB SAFE OF $1,000; Two Men Enter the Prudential Company's Flatbush Office and Overpower the Cashier.
leadPara: Having been overpowered by two men who represented themselves to be employes of the New York Telephone Company, Miss Alice Brenneis, 19 years old, cashier at the branch office of the Prudential Life Insurance Company at 248 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, was bound and gagged there yesterday afternoon.

headline: HEDGES HITS AT SULZER.; No Tammany Man, He Says, Can Raise the Moral Tone of the State.
leadPara: SYRACUSE, Oct. 29. -- After a day of hard campaigning, making thirteen speeches in towns and villages between Rochester and this city, Job E. Hedges, Republican candidate for Governor, arrived in Syracuse to-night and addressed at the Arena the largest political rally of the Onondaga campaign.
abstract: Hedges assails Sulzer, s, Syracuse

headline: ORDERS NUGENT INDICTED.; Court Asks Why He Should Be Made an Exception by Grand Jury.
leadPara: The failure of the last Essex County Grand Jury to act in case of City Counsel James R. Nugent of Newark, who figured in a primary election row, led Judge Martin yesterday to charge the new Grand Jury specifically on the case and instruct the jurors to make a new investigation of the charges against Nugent and others who figured with him in the episode.

headline: 1892 AND 1912.
leadPara: The Democrats "swept the country" in the Congressional elections of 1890, as they swept the country in the Congressional and State elections of 1910. The McKinley bill turned the people against the Republicans in 1890, as the Payne-Aldrich bill and the broken pledges of the platform turned the people against them in 1910.

Aldcrofft, Jr., resigned is thought to strengthen the so-called progressive element in that body to such a degree that it is believed by some that Commissioner Thomas W. Churchill will be elected President of the board next February if he should again be a candidate for that office.

leadPara: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- "No man would care to have his State fail him, but, wholly apart from selfish reasons, I want to see Ohio go Republican by a large majority," said President Taft in a letter to Fred A. Geler of Cincinnati, which was made public to-day at the White House.

headline: WILSON IN NEWARK WINS HIS ENEMIES; Nugent on Reception Committee Meets Him, and Stays Around -- A Blow for Taft.
leadPara: Carrying out his policy of absolute frankness with the voters which has characterized all of his addresses, Gov. Woodrow Wilson spent yesterday campaigning in Essex County, N.J., the stronghold of the machine headed by ex-United States Senator James Smith, Jr., and James R. Nugent.

headline: LINE-UP OF WILSON PARADE WORKED OUT; First Division Swings Into Broadway at Maiden Lane Exactly at Noon Saturday.
leadPara: The formation of the big Wilson-Sulzer parade on Saturday was made public yesterday. The first division will form in Maiden Lane east of Broadway and it will swing into the promptly at noon. The Grand Marshal, Street Cleaning Commissioner Edwards, his staff, and dismounted and mounted aids followed by at band, will head the procession.

headline: REPUBLICANS CANNOT COUNT MONROE SAFE; Democrats Likely to Capture Stronghold Which Heretofore Has Been Impregnable.
leadPara: ROCHESTER, Oct. 29. -- It is a toss-up between the two old parties in Monroe County this year, judging from all surface indications. In other Presidential years Monroe has been looked to for an impressive Republican majority, and it has always made good. Not even in 1892 was it carried from its Republican moorings on the Democratic tide that swept Grover Cleveland into the White House.
abstract: other Bull Moose campaign developments

headline: ERIE PROGRESSIVES GOOD CAMPAIGNERS; Bernhardt's Famous Bean Poll Gives Them Rosy Hopes -- Republicans Gloomy.
leadPara: BUFFALO, Oct. 30. -- In other localities the political leaders who are not taking chances make careful house-to-house canvasses of the voters in order to arrive at some conclusion as to how the election will go. Straw votes, generally speaking, are looked upon as indicating how the wind blows, but are not regarded as infallible. But Buffalonians without exception swear by "Bernhardt's bean poll."
abstract: Erie County

leadPara: BURLINGTON, N.J., Oct. 30. -- Entering the Republican strongholds in Southern New Jersey to-day, Gov. Woodrow Wilson put before the voters what he believes to be the paramount need of the whole campaign: the complete control of the Government by the Democratic Party.

headline: SHERMAN ALWAYS ALLIED TO MACHINE; Was a Skilled Parliamentarian and Leader in Congress, Suave and Tactful.
leadPara: Vice President James Schoolcraft Sherman was born in Utica, N.Y., on Oct. 24, 1855, and received his education at private schools and at Hamilton College, from which he was graduated with the class of 1878. Then he studied law and was admitted to the bar two years later, when he became a member of the firm of Cockinham Martin.
