headline: ROOSEVELT READY TO TALK TO-NIGHT; Goes Over Speech He'll Make in the Garden with Senator Dixon and G.W. Perkins.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, Oct. 31. -- Senator Dixon and George W. Perkins dined to-night with Col. Roosevelt at Sagamore Hill. Following the dinner the Colonel talked with the Senator and Mr. Perkins on the situation in New York and in New Jersey. The text of Mr. Roosevelt's speech which will be delivered to-morrow night at Madison Square Garden was also reviewed.

Straus, the Progressive candidate for Governor, last night, and demanded that he cease "proclaiming in the up-State sections where there are no Jews that I, William Sulzer, am a Russian Jew."

leadPara: Oscar Straus, the Bull Moose candidate for Governor, talked to the people in his own home district at Leslie Hall, Broadway and Eighty-third Street, and then invaded the home district of his opponent, William Sulzer, at Stuyvesant Casino, in a tour of the city last night in which he addressed eight meetings and more than 12,000 persons.

headline: ROOSEVELT LETS CHEERS GO ON; Prendergast Had Appealed to Garden Crowd to Desist When Colonel Raised Left Hand.
leadPara: He came to town again last night, doctors or no doctors. They told him to stay home or he might get something the matter with him, but you can't argue with the Colonel. He laughed his doctors blithely to scorn, climbed aboard an automobile, and had himself taken down to the 3:55 train for New York, and he got here at 5:30.

headline: West Point Football Game Canceled.
leadPara: WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- The football game which was to have been played here to-morrow between the Army and Holy Cross has been canceled. Orders were received from the Secretary of War suspending all duties at this post to-morrow on account of the death of Vice President Sherman, and the football game was accordingly called off.
abstract: West Point cancels football game

leadPara: In a whirlwind trip, beginning at the Manhattan Casino, 155th Street and Eighth Avenue, and ending at Cooper Union, William Sulzer spoke last night at eight meetings. To the 15,000 persons who heard him in the course of the night he prophesied a Democratic victory in the State and Nation.

headline: SAW THE TIDE TURN WITH SULTAN'S ARMY; Correspondents in Auto Witnessed Dash of Reinforcements to Meet Flank Attack.
leadPara: FOUR MILES SOUTHEAST OF LULE-BURGAS, Wednesday, Oct. 30. -- It is noon, and the bang and boom of field guns, near and distant, and the manifold rattle of a fierce rifle fire are the sounds among which this telegram is written.

headline: IBSEN'S SON APPEARS IN THE FIELD OF LITERATURE; Only Child of the Dramatist and Godson and Son-in-Law of Bjornson Expounds a Philosophy of His Own in a Volume Entitled "Human Quintessence" --- "An Effort at Pure Reason."
leadPara: A NEW book by Ibsen that is what is promised for the shelves this Winter. But, lest the countless lovers of Nora be disappointed, let it be heralded at the outset as a new book by a new Ibsen. For the author is Dr. Sigurd Ibsen. It will be the appearance in English of the first book from the pen of the son and only child of Henrik Ibsen.

headline: California.
MOOSE LEADER THREATENED.; Georgia Progressive Goes Armed in Fear of Being Shot.
leadPara: ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 2. -- C.W. McClure, Progressive National Committeeman from Georgia, is carrying a shotgun leaded with slugs to defend himself against a man who in a letter has threatened to kill him on sight. The letter was signed "A Hater," and told McClure that of he continued his connection with the Moose Club he would be killed before Tuesday.

headline: LONG SCORES ROOSEVELT.; Former Secretary of Navy Says Temperament Unfits Him for President.
leadPara: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 2. -- John D. Long, who, while Secretary of the Navy, had Theodore Roosevelt as assistant, denounces the National Progressive Party as a "purely personal party," in writing on the "Candidacy of President Taft" in The Harvard Illustrated Magazine. He says the party owes its existence merely to the fact that Roosevelt was disappointed in his quest for the regular Republican nomination.
abstract: former Navy Sec Long scores Roosevelt

headline: AMERICAN FASHIONS.
leadPara: Ever since THE TIMES a few weeks ago gave expression to Mr. EDWARD BOK'S views on American fashions there has been wide comment of the subject on the part of newspapers through the country, and the "trade" journals in the field of textiles and women's wear are devoting much space to the discussion.
abstract: ed on Amer fashions

headline: WEST VIRGINIA FOR WILSON.; Indications Point to a Democratic Sweep, with Taft a Poor Third.
leadPara: WHEELING, West Va., Nov. 2. -- The indications in West Virginia an the eve of the election are that Woodrow Wilson will sweep the State, and that Col. Roosevelt will poll 15,000 more votes than Mr. Taft, and that the State will elect five and perhaps six Democratic Congressmen and a Democratic Legislature, insuring the election of Democratic successor to Senator C.W. Watson.

headline: JOHNSON CLUB FOR COLONEL.; Cleveland Progressive Democrats Declare Gov. Wilson Too Narrow.
leadPara: CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 2. -- The Tom L. Johnson Club, an organization of progressive Democrats, named after the former Mayor who gave Cleveland a three-cent fare, adopted to-day a resolution indorsing Roosevelt for President. The club has a large membership and has been fighting some of the machine projects of Mayor Newton D. Baker, ex-Mayor Johnson's chief lieutenant, who is now the head of the Cuyahoga County Democracy.

headline: JERSEY OUTLOOK PUZZLES LEADERS; Situation Has Changed So in a Week That All Political Forecasts Are Upset.
leadPara: The political situation in New Jersey has changed to such an extent in the last week that the previous forecasts as to the outcome of the voting on Tuesday have been completely upset. The National and State Democratic Committees still maintain that Gov. Wilson will carry his home State, but the figures they quote show that they are not by any means so confident as they were earlier in the campaign.
abstract: NY election estimates

headline: A BERLIN BYE-ELECTION.; " Kaiser Seat" Again Being Contested -Radical's Chances Good.
leadPara: BERLIN, Nov. 2. -- Berlin is to have an exciting election of its own next Tuesday. Herr Kampf, the President of the Reichstag, recently resigned from the representation of the so-called "Kaiser Seat," the first Berlin parliamentary district, on account of a allegation of frauds at the election last January, when he squeezed in by the narrow majority of nine votes over his Social Democratic rival.

headline: JOB HEDGES REPLIES TO MOOSE HECKLER; Quiets Republican Club Rally to Answer Query as to Removing Gaynor and Waldo.
leadPara: In a whirlwind automobile tour of the city last night Job E. Hedges, Republican candidate for Governor, made his final appeal for the support of the electorate in Manhattan Island.

headline: ILLINOIS LEANS TO COLONEL.; Legislature, with Two Senators at Stake, Is in Doubt.
leadPara: CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- While the political managers of the Republican, Democratic, and Progressive Parties each claim Illinois, impartial observers of conditions are strongly of the opinion that Col. Theodore Roosevelt has a better chance than Wilson or Taft to carry the State. If there is anything in the nature of a Roosevelt landslide here, he will carry Frank II.

headline: MARYLAND NOT CLOSE NOW.; Moosers a Bad Third on Registration, but May Prove Strong.
leadPara: BALTIMORE, Nov. 2. -- Maryland seems assure for Wilson as Texas. It appears to be only a question of plurality. In 1908 Taft's plurality over Bryan was only 136 out of a total vte of 222,370, and in 1904 Roosevelt's plurality was but 81 in a total of 218,943. If it were not for the split in the Republican Party Maryland's vote this time would be very close.

headline: STRAUS IN BROOKLYN WINDS UP CAMPAIGN; Reads the Colonel's Message to Audience of 4,000 at the Academy of Music.
leadPara: Oscar S. Straus, the Bull Moose candidate for Governor, wound up his-campaign last night with nine speeches, the last of which was delivered to a crowd of 4,000 persons in the Academy of Music, Brooklyn. Eariler in the evening he had toured Harlem and Manhattan, closing his fight with vigorous attacks on William Sulzer, the Democratic candidate.
abstract: Straus winds up campaign with 9 ss in Bklyn

headline: BITTER FIGHT IN INDIANA.
Coats Are Long and Skirts Remain Narrow---Little Trouble Altering Last Season's Garments.

headline: CONNECTICUT RACE CLOSE.; Wilson Seems to Have a Slight Lead -- Legislature in Doubt.
leadPara: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 2. -- Claims of carrying the State next Tuesday were made to-day by the Republican, Democratic, and Progressive Party managers. Chairman Forster of the Democratic State Central Committee cites 25,000 as the probable plurality of Wilson and Gov. Baldwin. State Senator Henry Roraback, who has had charge of Taft's campaign, sets 30,000 as the figure that Taft and Judge John P. Studley, Republican candidate for Governor, will have.

headline: HITS WILSON'S TRUST RECORD.; Roosevelt Asks Why He Didn't Prosecute Them as Governor.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, Nov. 2. -- Col. Roosevelt to-day made a direct assault upon Gov. Wilson's position on the trust question, and be went after the Governor hammer and tongs. He went into Wilson's record as Governor of New Jersey, showing how from his standpoint the Governor had failed to do the least thing to curb the trusts.

headline: TAFT GAINS IN WISCONSIN.; Movement Towards Him, However, Seems to Have Started Too Late.
leadPara: MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 2. -- "If the election were to take place one month from now, I would be willing to bet, if I were a betting man, that President Taft would carry Wisconsin. As it is, though he is gaining steadily, it seems doubtful if he can overcome the claims of the Democrats that Wilson is the real hope of the old party progressives."

headline: NEBRASKA IN DOUBT.; Wilson's Chances Look Best -- Close Race, with Roosevelt Likely.
leadPara: LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 2. -- Political currents in Nebraska this year are so chaotic that the prophets have mostly taken to cover.

headline: SULZER KEEPS UP ATTACK ON STRAUS; In Winding Up Campaign His Speeches Are Directed Against Progressive Candidate.

headline: TAFT THIRD IN PENNSYLVANIA.; Wilson Seems to Have the Advantage Over Roosevelt.
leadPara: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2. -- Although the State Chairman of each of the three leading parties -- Republican, Democratic, and Progressive -- is claiming the State for his candidates, an unbiased estimate of the probable outcome in Pennsylvania on Tuesday is: Wilson first, Roosevelt second, and Taft third.

headline: THEORETICAL PROGRESS.
leadPara: There was reported yesterday one of several recent cases by which it is possible to test practically the theoretical benefits of social justice as expounded by candidates for popular favor in the pending election. headline: ROOSEVELT SOUNDS MOOSE TRUMPET CALL; In Final Appeal to Voters He Says Old Parties Are Wedded to Issues of a Dead Past.
leadPara: OYSTER BAY, N.Y., Nov. 3. -- At the end of the hardest campaign of his career in politics Col. Roosevelt to-night made a final appeal to the voters of the country on behalf of the Progressive ticket. Except for two speeches to-morrow in his home county, he had ended the struggle which has kept him hard at work since he threw his hat into the ring last Spring.

Wilson as the only candidate who could be relied upon to break the power of the trusts.

headline: PRESIDENT ISSUES A FINAL APPEAL; Democratic Policy Will Halt Prosperity, Paralyze Business, and Bring a Panic, He Says.
leadPara: President Taft, before departing for Cincinnati last night, issued a final appeal to the voters of the country to support hits. If the economic views of the Democratic Party were put into force, he said, it would mean the halting of prosperity and the paralyzing of business, as well as bringing a return of the experience the country went through from 1893 to 1897.

headline: CONGRESSMAN UTTER DEAD.; Was Candidate for Re-election -- Z.W. Bliss Named in His Place.
leadPara: PROVIDENCE, Nov. 3. -- Congressman George H. Utter died at his home in Westerly this afternoon after an illness of about three weeks. Cancer of the liver was the cause of death, Mr. Utter became ill in Washington. After a few days he was removed to the Providence Hospital, and an operation was performed which was primarily for gall stones.

headline: CAMPAIGN CHEERS IN CHURCH; Mention of Roosevelt's Name Brings Applause and Hisses.

Percy Stickney Grant prevented last night's political speeches in the Church of the Ascension at Fifth Avenue and Eleventh Street, from creating unecclesiastical disorder. As it was, the mention of Theodore Roosevelt's named caused an outbreak of applause in the church, followed by a rebuking round of hissing, and the pastor had to issue a warning against a recurrence of the demonstration.

headline: IDEALISM, BUT NOT PARTISANSHIP.

In a report of Dr. HOLMES'S sermon last Sunday, when President TAFT was in the congregation, THE TIMES said that the clergyman had carefully prepared "a Bull Moose sermon," which he delivered, in spite of the President's presence, of which he was not aware until he mounted the pulpit.

headline: WILSON FIRST, TAFT SECOND.
leadPara: The first and vital object to be accomplished to-day is the election of WOODROW WILSON. It is next in importance that Mr. TAFT should lead Mr. ROOSEVELT in the Electoral and the popular vote. It has for many years been desirable that political power in the Nation should be transferred from the Republicans to the Democrats.

Marshall Vice President by an Electoral majority which challenged comparison with the year in which Horace Greeley was defeated by Grant. headline: THE STATE LEGISLATURE.

headline: NEW YORK TURNS OUT AN EARLY VOTE; Nearly All Election Districts Had Their Lists Checked Off at Noon.

headline: Article 34 -- No Title
leadPara: BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 5. -- Woodrow Wilson carried Maryland by from 20,000 to 25,000 plurality, estimated from figures received up to 11 o'clock to-night. Roosevelt ran second and Taft third. In Southern Maryland and on the Eastern Shore Taft led Roosevelt, but the Progressive candidate's vote in Baltimore City and Western Maryland exceeded that of the President in the rest of the State.

headline: WILSON HAS 442 ELECTORAL VOTES; Roosevelt Has But 77 as the Result of Illinois Going to Democrats.
leadPara: Roosevelt lost 29 Electoral votes yesterday as the result of Illinois, the State which the Progressives all along felt surest of carrying, swinging over to Wilson. The Democratic vote in the Electoral College was thereby increased to 442. Roosevelt's dropped to 77, with Michigan, Minnesota, Pennsylvania, South Dakota, and Washington safely in his column, and Taft kept his 12 votes from Utah, Idaho, and Vermont.

headline: BULL MOOSE TO HORN ALBANY LAWMAKERS; Permanent Committee Will Prod Legislature in Interest of Progressive Laws.

headline: PERKINS TRIUMPHS; BIG MOOSE YARD HERE; Chairman Defeats Progressive Foes by Having Party Headquarters Kept in New York.
leadPara: CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 11. -- George W. Perkins won a complete triumph over all opposition in the meeting of the Progressive National Committee to-day. He had the National headquarters removed to New York, put through his plan for branch bureaus, and then announced that the next official business of the Progressive Party would be a meeting of the Executive Committee at the Hotel Manhattan in New York City on Dec. 18.
abstract: conf session; Perkins wins victory by having natl hdqrs transferred to NYC; recall of party leaders approved; other developments

headline: Article 9 -- No Title
leadPara: CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- Jack Johnson's attorney's, W.B. Anderson and E.H. Wright, appeared in the United States District Court to-day to ask that their names be stricken from the records as counsel to the fighter. The lawyers, who also are negroes, said Johnson's recent marriage with Lucile Cameron, a white girl. was disapproved by them to such an extent that they did not care to be associated with him longer.
abstract: exposition opens

headline: A PERSONAL PARTY.
leadPara: Mr. ROOSEVELT bears himself royally. His passage from one stage to another in Chicago has all the impressiveness of a "King's progress." His utterances have the authoritative tone of a speech from the throne. His gracious recognition of PERKINS, FLINN, and MUNSEY -- who, "when there was no definite "plan for obtaining finances, so gen- "erously came forward with their sub- "scriptions" -- was in true monarchical style and temper.
abstract: ed on Roosevelt speeches at conf

headline: MOOSE BACK FROM CHICAGO.; Straus Sure Now the Party Will Endure -- A Slap from Barnes.
leadPara: A train load of Bull Moosers returned from the National Progressive Conference at Chicago on a special train, reaching the Grand Central Station at 5:30 yesterday afternoon. Col. Theodore Roosevelt was not among them. He will be back to-day. George W. Perkins, executive head of the Bull Moose movement, is not expected until Saturday.
abstract: conf ends; Straus, back in NYC, comments on conf results; says party will endure

headline: ROOSEVELT ON WAY EAST.; Dixon Pleased with the Chicago Progressive Conference.
leadPara: CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- Col. Roosevelt departed for New York at 10:15 o'clock this morning, after having spent three days in the Progressive conference here. He was escorted to the station in an auto by Robert P. Bass, Governor of New Hampshire and Medill McCormick. There was no demonstration.
abstract: New bldg to be opened by Cardinal Farley

headline: FATHER SPOILS A MELODRAMA; Turn Up to Refute Self-Styled Orphan's Tale of Woe.
leadPara: Even the attendants in the Children's Court, accustomed to stories of suffering, swallowed hard on Thursday to choke back the lumps which came in their throats as fifteen-year-old Madeline Kessler of Montvale, N.J., told her pitiful orphan's tale entitled "Only a Nickel Left."

headline: GOOD WILL TOWARD MEN; A Lay Sermon of Cheer and Counsel Is Here Preached.
leadPara: One night nearly two thousand years ago, while shepherds were watching their flocks on Judean plains, a great light suddenly appeared in the heavens, and the air was palpitant with the singing of an invisible choir high-seated among the distant stars, and thus was ushered in the beginning of a new era in the life of the world.

headline: LEAGUE MAY GO OFF BALLOT.; Canvassers Uncertain Whether It Polled Enough Votes.
leadPara: ALBANY, Dec. 14. -- When the State Board of Canvassers meets on Monday to tabulate the vote cast in this State in the last election, it will be called on to decide whether the Independence League is entitled to retain its place on the ballot as a regular party organization. To have that privilege, a party is required to poll at least 10,000 votes for its candidate for Governor.
abstract: Independence League may lose place on ballot in next election because it failed to poll sufficient votes in Nov election

headline: BRYCE GETS MEDAL OF PENNSYLVANIANS; Their Award for Distinguished Services Goes to a Foreigner for the First Time.
leadPara: Nearly 1,000 members of the Pennsylvania Society and their guests crowded the grand ballroom, galleries and adjoining rooms in the Waldorf-Astoria last night at the fourteenth annual dinner held to commemorate the one hundred and twenty-fifth anniversary of the framing of the Constitution of the United States. James Bryce, the retiring British Ambassador, was the guest of honor.
abstract: Dinner, NYC, commem framing of US Const; Amb J Bryce 1st foreigner ever to be awarded gold medal; he, others s; guests listed

headline: DANCES AND DOUBTS; Is There Any Progress in the Terpsichorean Art?

THE SOCIAL MEANING OF THE BRITISH DIVORCE REPORT; Prof. G.E. Howard of University of Nebraska Believes It Will Start a Revolution That Will Affect the Nature of the Family Bond and Transform Some of the Basic Ideals of the Household Life.
leadPara: IF sanctioned by Parliament, the recommendations of the majority report of the "British Royal Commission on Divorce and Matrimonial Causes" will almost surely start a revolution which will affect the nature of the family bond and transform some of the basic ideals of the household life.

headline: MUNSEY TO LOSE $500,000.; Says Support of Rosevelt Will Cost Him Much Advertising.

headline: BOOMS BRYAN FOR CABINET.; No Place Too Good for Him, Says Senator Martine of New Jersey.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- On the eve of Gov. Wilson's return to the United States, Democratic Senators are convinced, by information from various sources, that William Jennings Bryan will sit in the next Cabinet as Secretary of State, whether or not the formal tender has been made or accepted.
abstract: Dem Sens certain Wilson will give Bryan a Cabinet post; Sen J E Martine comments

headline: THE DEMOCRATIC OPPORTUNITY.
leadPara: The Democrats have a strong position in this State, which they have won largely through the deep rift in the Republican ranks. There is among some of the leaders a tendency to try to confirm this position by measures that will appeal to the radical or "Progressive" sentiment which has split the Opposition.
abstract: Editorial urges Dems simplify elections by adopting short ballot

headline: Progressives Second in Chicago.
leadPara: CHICAGO, Dec. 16. -- The Progressive Party is to succeed the Republican as the minority party in Cook County, according to a decision by Judge Owens in the County Court to-day. The Election Commissioners were instructed by the court to recognize the Progressives instead of the Republicans in selecting Judges and clerks of election.
abstract: Ct rules Progressive Party is to succeed Repub as minority party in Cook County, Ill

headline: BULL MOOSE PLANS LEGISLATIVE REFORM; Its Few Representatives Will Have Bills to Destroy the Powers That Be.
leadPara: Through its Legislative Committee the National Progressive Party is preparing to submit to the Legislature, when it meets next month, a complete legislative programme, based on the Progressive platform adopted at the Syracuse Convention. The Bull Moose Legislative Committee, working in conjunction with a number of other committees, is now preparing the bills.
abstract: Progressive Party to submit legis program based on platform adopted at its state conv

headline: PROGRESSIVES TO RULE,; But Chairmanship of Senate Committees to be Left to Old Leaders.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Ever since a month before Congress convened Democratic Senators, in casual meetings and informal conferences, have discussed the organization of the next Senate, when the rolls would show a bare Democratic majority. Since Congress convened this informal consultation has proceeded more rapidly in the cloakrooms and on the floor of the Senate.
abstract: Dem Sens tacitly accept plan of reorgn to retain old conservative Dems as com leaders

headline: WILSON LIKES BRYAN AND IGNORES CRITICS; Much Interested in Letters Naming Nebraskan for Secretary of State and Not in Others.
abstract: Wilson warns he will 'hang' any man who starts a panic, s, Southern Soc of NY

headline: ELECT N.Y.A.C. COMMITTEE.; Members Indorse the Original List of Seven for Nominating Committee.
leadPara: A radical departure was inaugurated by the New York Athletic Club last night in the selection of the Nominating Committee. Instead of the committee being selected by the Board of Governors, the club members elected the committee of seven to name officers for election in the January elections by the club.

headline: SCRAMBLE FOR CRANE'S SEAT; Massachusetts Legislature May Be Deadlocked on Senatorship.
leadPara: BOSTON, Dec. 17. -- Politicians are looking forward to the coming meeting of the Great and General Court, or Legislature, of Massachusetts, because of the promised wrangle over the choice of a United States Senator in succession to Mr. Crane. Although the Legislature is comfortably Republican, a deadlock is in sight.
abstract: Gives up law practice

headline: TREASON IN MOOSE CAMP?; Judge Lindsey of Colorado Charged with Working Against Cause.
leadPara: DENVER, Dec. 18. -- Treason and conspiracy have broken out in the Bull Moose organizations of Denver and Colorado. Treason is charged to Judge Ben B. Lindsey and conspiracy against Lindsey's opponents, who have banded together to drive him out of the Progressive Party of Colorado.

headline: GOVERNOR DEFENDS REMOVAL OF O'RYAN; With a Choice of Two Posts, He Took the One Without Salary.
leadPara: ALBANY, Dec. 18. -- Gov. Dix gave out this evening a statement covering his action in nominating Gen. John F. O'Ryan for Major General of the National Guard and his subsequent order relegating the General to the supernumerary list, with the following order of Attorney General Carmody to permit Gen. O'Ryan to test the legality of his removal.

headline: BARONESS WINSLOE KILLED.; Former Miss Edith Stone Victim of an Accident in India.
leadPara: NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 18. -- Word that Baroness Winsloe had been killed in a carriage accident yesterday was received here to-night in a cablegram from Bareilly, India.
abstract: Exec com to conf, NYC, on details of future mgt

headline: WILSON'S STATE PLURALITY.; Carried New York by 200,047 -- Sulzer's Plurality Over Hedges, 205,454.
leadPara: ALBANY, Dec. 19. -- Woodrow Wilson, President-elect, carried New York State at the November election by a plurality of 200,047 over President William H. Taft, according to the official canvass completed by the State Board of Canvassers to-day. The Progressive vote for Theodore Roosevelt was 65,407 less than the vote for President Taft.

BULL MOOSE ADOPT A WORKING PLAN; Publicity Bureau in Washington and National Headquarters Here -- Committees Named.
leadPara: After conferring for two whole days, the Executive Committee of the National Progressive Committee adjourned last night with the announcement that a pretty complete plan "for the more thorough organization and division of the work for carrying on the propaganda of the Progressive Party" had been adopted.
abstract: conf; adopts working plans for orgn and div of publicity; will open publicity hdqrs in Washington

headline: MURPHY DODGES A BRYAN ATTACK; Stays Away from Sulzer Dinner, Where Commoner Chants the Dirge of Boss Rule.

headline: ENGLISH FOLLOW AMERICA IN TENNIS; Britons Adopt Rule for Champions to Play Through in Order to Retain Title.
leadPara: England's lawn tennis players are moving along parallel with the Americans in the effort to establish an international standard of rules and conditions surrounding the game. The annual meeting of the English Lawn Tennis Association was recently held in London.

THE DRINKING NATIONS; Not Great by Drink, and England Is Now Sober.

headline: INSIDE THE WAR CIRCLE SURROUNDING ADRIANOPLE
leadPara: Mustapha Pasha, Nov. 19. WE are within 20 miles of Adrianople. Around Adrianople is a ring of Turkish guns and soldiers. Holding them in is a ring of Bulgarian guns and soldiers. There is still another ring.

headline: NEW YORK'S BOARD OF ALDERMEN ARCHAIC, SAYS FOSDICK; Former Commissioner of Accounts Points Out What He Considers the Greatest Flaw in the City's Governmental System, and Tells How It Might Be Remedied.
leadPara: THAT one of the real flaws in New York's municipal government lies in the existence of its Board of Aldermen is the opinion of Raymond B. Fosdick, until recently Commissioner of Accounts and one of the most careful students of the problems of municipal government in the United States.

headline: SUFFRAGIST PILGRIMS MEET VINCENT ASTOR; Not Interested, He Tells Them, When They Offer Votes for Women Literature.

headline: ADRIANOPLE TURKS SAVED THE CAPITAL; Mr. Palmer Tells How Their Desperate Resistance Upset the Whole Bulgarian Advance.
leadPara: The minarets of Sultan Selim! Needlelike, I have seen them rise over the indistinct mass of Adrianople from the distant hills, then as substantial columns from the nearby hills, and again so close from the shellproof of an advanced infantry position that I could make out the tilings on the dome of the great mosque itself.

headline: PROGRESSIVES HAVE A PLAN.; Will Give Older Senators One Chairmanship -- Others to be Distributed.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Members of Congress who are in Washington were interested to-day in dispatches from Lincoln telling of Mr. Bryan's editorial in The Commoner, urging progressive Democrats in Congress, particularly those in the Senate, to disregard the seniority rule in making committee assignments.

headline: DOES IT MEAN WAR?
leadPara: We take it that Mr. BRYAN is not going to be a member of President WILSON'S Cabinet. The evidence is inferential, but it cannot be disregarded. It is to be found in an editorial article which appeared yesterday in Mr. BRYAN'S Commoner, published at Lincoln, Neb., here reprinted:

headline: VERBECK HEADS THE GUARD.; Dix Names Him as Major General -- Sulzer Will Really Decide.
leadPara: ALBANY, Dec. 27. -- Adjt. Gen. William Verbeck was appointed Major General of the National Guard of the State by Gov. Dix to-day to succeed Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, retired. He will act both as Major General and Adjutant General until Jan. 1, when he will be succeeded as Adjutant General by Henry D. Hamilton of Brooklyn, who will be an appointee of Governor-elect Sulzer.

headline: MR. BRYAN'S MOTIVE.
leadPara: There are many reasons for the belief that Mr. BRY, wrote with malice prepense his Commoner article advising the "progressive" Democrats in Congress to disregard the principle of seniority in committee assignments in the Senate and House, to the end that none but trusted "progressives" may get the Chairmanships and the places that control the committees.

headline: COLUMBIA'S CHESS TITLE.; Champions Rout Princeton in Deciding Game for Championship.
leadPara: For the third time in succession Columbia won the annual chess tournament, the twenty-first of the series with Harvard, Yale, and Princeton, by taking three points out of four from Princeton in the match postponed from the first round and played off at the rooms of the Progressive Chess Club at the Cafe Monopol yesterday.

headline: NEW YEAR'S EVE SPECULATION.
leadPara: In Chicago ticket speculators are expecting to make large profits out of their forehanded reservation of tables in the hotels and restaurants for New Year's Eve. Thus far the chances seem to favor them. They are now asking four times the original prices for reserved tables.
abstract: Editorial speculating on number of New Yr's Eve revelers

headline: Article 5 -- No Title
BULL MOOSE VOTE DUE TO SOCIALISTS; Kirchwey Says They Started the Movement Which Made Rooseveltism Possible.
OUTLOOK FOR RAILWAYS GOOD; Officials Say That 1913 Promises to be a Prosperous Year.
leadPara: If the expectations of some of the leading railway officers of the United States are realized, the coming year will prove to be one of the best business periods on record. Answers received by The Railway Age Gazette from a number of Presidents and Vice Presidents to the question, "How do you regard the business prospects of the railways for the calendar year 1913?"
abstract: Ry Age Gazette poll of rr officials repts '13 business outlook favorable

headline: THE BRITISH INSURANCE ACT.
leadPara: When the terms of the British insurance act were first made known 27,400 doctors signed a personal pledge not to accept service under it. The profession is still bitter about it, but the revolt is now less vigorous, and there seems an improving prospect that the doctors may co-operate with the Government after all.

headline: Marty O'Toole Married.
leadPara: FRAMINGHAM, Mass., Dec. 29. -- Martin J. O'Toole of this city, famous in baseball circles as the $22,500 pitcher of the Pittsburgh Pirates, was married to-day at Saxonville, a nearby town, to Miss Rose Heffernan of that place. Following a honeymoon trip to Bermuda, Mr. and Mrs. O'Toole will reside in Boston until March, when Marty will join the Pirates for the training trip to Hot Springs, Ark.

headline: Article 2 -- No Title
leadPara: WASHINTON, Dec. 30. -- The movement started in the West and Middle West by bankers and business men seeking to bring about the selection of James J. Hill as Secretary of Agriculture in the Wilson Cabinet meets with the warm approval of Senator Henry L. Myers, a Progressive Democrat from Montana.

headline: Obituary 1 -- No Title
MISS INGERSOLL MARRIES.; Colonel's Daughter Weds W. McL. Probasco by Ethical Ritual.
leadPara: Miss Maude Ingersoll, daughter of the late Robert G. Ingersoll, was married to Wallace McLean Probasco son of Wallace Probasco of Cincinnati, Ohio, at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon at the home of her mother, 117 East Twenty-first Street.

headline: WILSON MEN PLAN U. S. SENATE FIGHT; Conference at Trenton to Keep Important Chairmanships from Reactionaries.
leadPara: TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 30. -- For thirty minutes this afternoon, in the outer office of Gov. Wilson, a group of Senators and Senators-elect discussed in spirited fashion a plan to reorganize from the bottom up the United States Senate for its first Democratic session.
abstract: Group of Sens and Sens-elect map plan to reorganize Sen and keep important chmnships from reactionaries
